â€œHere is your stairs to heaven. Those steps are your sins Grover, all 1,048,576 of â€˜em! You think yours is long? Wait til youâ€™ve seen mine!â€™ Kermit said to Grover.

Grover has accepted the challenge to  climb the stairway to heaven. Each step marks a sin that he has committed in his past life. The bigger the sin, the bigger the step. If he climbs the entire thing, heâ€™ll face judgement based on his efforts. Unfortunately, Grover made plenty of sins, about 1,048,376 of â€˜em, and the stairs will turn into a slide every 7 days. But none of it deters Grover, he brought the Glock with him. Even if it does take an eternity to master the flight of stairs, he would be the muppet to kill God.


The stairs have yet to turn into a slide at seven days end, and those larger steps that were his grave steps were no match for his thirst to shoot and kill God. After only 6 days, 23 hours and 35 minutes, Grover has ascended most of the 1,048,576 steps to heaven. But to his shock, Kermit was up there waiting for him. 

â€œHow can this be!!â€ Yelled Grover, â€œYou were supposed to climb your own stairs, and it was bigger than mine, right!?â€ 

With a calm demeanor, Kermit answered him. â€œYouâ€™ve come a long way for your purpose, my child. But next week, letâ€™s get serious and lay a foot on every step so you donâ€™t look like a furry blue cheater.â€ Then Grover got his face kicked, and fell to the bottom. 

After many failures, Grover finally made it to heaven again at the top of his sinful steps. And this time, he remembered to push Kermit down before going in to complete his primary mission. As Grover concentrated on where God might be, he noticed a growing glow all around him. His teeth began vibrating as it reached a blinding crescendo, forcing him to shut his eyes tightly as he waited for his nemesis to appear. His head felt to be in the grip of a closing vice. In a terrified frenzy his words jumbled and somehow cried out. 

â€œShow me GOD!â€
Instantly the buzzing and glowing stopped. Grover began to see himself in a puddle at his feet.

It stared him in the face. He had usurped God. He was handed down ultimate power in the moment of Kermitâ€™s collapse, and it now in control of every aspect in the cosmos. The sun and moon, good and evil, and all the things sacred are in his hands to maintain alone. 

That was never part of the plan. Grover intended to shoot God. And by God, he will. 

â€œGod? Where are you at you pale-ass bitch? Iâ€™m here for you, and Iâ€™ve got nothing to lose other than this gun I stole before I died!â€

Grover didnâ€™t get a response. 

â€œI know youâ€™re hiding, I get it! Bertstrips werenâ€™t supposed to be invented!â€

Grover looked around for a few minutes before he realized God isnâ€™t here. 

At this point he wondered if God was the Green frog he just shoved down the stairs. But in any case, he kept his guard up. 

God punishes Grover by flinging him out of the gates to heaven. Doomed to fall down the infinite staircase while breaking every bone in his body till the end of time.

How long has it been? Years? No, not years. Not decades, not centuries. No time. There was no time. He was still thinking like a mortal,  Grover knew, the day he left earth was the last day heâ€™d ever be a part of. The moment before he entered the portal was the last time he had been a part of this world. Time is gone. All of eternity stretches forward forever. A single second, a million years. Itâ€™s all the same now.  The neon flashes of multicolored radiation that spilled forth from the distortion in deep space, the bright white of the world when he first entered the world. It had all melted together into a singular moment, a never ending eternity. Time was gone. On his quest to seek the unknown, Grover had become immortal.  Grover had died. He saw the birth of the universe, and he saw the heat death. And he could not tell the difference.

For those who dont understand 

A missile is a self-propelled, airborne weapon, typically using a rocket motor or jet engine for propulsion. It's designed to travel to a target, often guided by onboard sensors and control systems, and carry a warhead. Ballistic missiles use a parabolic trajectory powered by rockets during launch, while cruise missiles are powered by jet engines for continuous flight. 
Key components and how they work:
Propulsion:
Rocket motors: Burn fuel to create thrust, propelling the missile forward, as described in an article from the Nuclear Threat Initiative. 
Jet engines: Provide continuous thrust during flight, as seen in cruise missiles. 
Guidance and Control:
Aerodynamic controls: Use fins and control surfaces to steer the missile and stabilize it in flight. 
Thrust vectoring: For ballistic missiles, this involves directing the engine's thrust to control the missile's path. 
Guidance systems: These systems use various sensors (like infrared, radar, or optical sensors) to track the target and adjust the missile's trajectory, as explained in a Britannica article. 
Examples of guidance systems: Infrared seekers can target heat sources like jet engine exhausts, while radar-guided missiles use radar to lock onto the target. 
Launch:
Boosters: Solid or liquid rocket motors provide the initial thrust to launch the missile. 
Launch tubes: Missiles are sometimes launched from tubes, as seen in an article from HowStuffWorks. 
Flight:
Ballistic missiles: Follow a trajectory that arcs upwards before descending to the target. 
Cruise missiles: Fly at a flatter trajectory, typically at lower altitudes. 
Warhead:
The missile's payload, which is designed to cause damage at impact.

Pretty cool story, hereâ€™s mine:

I never believed the stories the adults told about the Boogeyman. They were just tales to scare kids, I thought. But that nightâ€¦ that night, I learned there was something far worse than I could have imagined.

It was an autumn evening. The moon was hidden behind thick clouds, and the village was wrapped in a dense fog. All the other children were in bed, but I couldnâ€™t sleep. The Boogeyman story kept echoing in my mind, but I wasnâ€™t scared. I quietly slipped out of my house, determined to prove it was just a story.The fog swallowed me whole as I entered the woods. Every step felt louder than it should have, like the earth itself was trying to trap me. There was no sound, just the eerie rustling of leaves beneath my feet. The deeper I walked, the more something felt wrong, as if I was being watched.

Then, I heard it. A faint whisper, like the wind. â€œLucaâ€¦â€

I froze. â€œWhoâ€™s there?â€ I asked, my voice trembling. But there was no answer, only the whispering fog.
Another whisper, closer this time. â€œCome play with me.â€
My heart began to race. I wanted to turn back, but I forced myself to keep going, telling myself it was nothing. But the deeper I went, the thicker the fog became, and the silence felt heavier, like it was pressing down on me.

And then, I saw it. A towering shadow, its eyes gleaming like black holes, its smile twisted and inhuman. It was the Boogeyman.

â€œYouâ€™re not afraid of me, Luca?â€ its voice slithered into my mind, like a cold breath. â€œCome play with me.â€

I tried to move, to scream, but my body wouldnâ€™t respond. It felt like the fog was holding me in place. The Boogeyman drew closer, his claws sharp and ready to tear everything away.â€Donâ€™t run, Luca,â€ it whispered. â€œIâ€™ve been waiting for you.â€I couldnâ€™t escape. The fear, the deep terror I had tried to deny, now felt like it was suffocating me. Its cold hands touched my face, sending a shock through my body. I saw something in its eyesâ€”my own face. Twisted. Distorted. It was as if I was becoming the Boogeyman, or maybe I always had been.

Its claws dug into my arm, and I felt the pull of something dark, something consuming. There was no escape. My fear had brought me here. I had called him.
The fog swallowed me entirely. The world went black.
Now, every night, when the fog settles and the silence takes over, I hear the whisper: â€œCome play with me, Luca.â€

And I know heâ€™s still there, always.

Lie Berry â€“ Soviet Edition 

Viktor Ivanovich was never the son they wanted. His parents staunch Party loyalists dreamed of a fencer who would bring glory to the Motherland. Composed. Victorious. A model Soviet youth. But the gym taught him silence, not discipline. He learned to breathe through bruised ribs and hide split lips from the mirror. His teammates didnâ€™t train. They punished.

When Viktor walked away to become a military officer, his family didnâ€™t protest. They simply erased him. No letters. No visits. Just absence. Like heâ€™d been purged from their personal archives.

Years later, silence returned.

Two librarians vanished from the State Archive of Revolutionary Memory. No struggle. No blood.

That night, Viktor stood on his balcony, cigarette trembling, when his neighbor emerged from the fog a old lady with a bowl of dark, violet berries.

â€œLie Berries,â€ she said. â€œThey donâ€™t lie. They just remember differently.â€

Viktor frowned.

â€œThey supposed to help me forget? Or make it all taste sweeter?â€

She smiled, gold tooth shining.

â€œThey reveal the parts your mind wonâ€™t let you see.â€

He hesitated. Then bit down.



 Memory Vault: Gym Inferno

His vision was blurred.

He was back in the gym but it was on fire. Soviet banners curled in flame. The air reeked of sweat, smoke, and scorched propaganda. The fencing mats had melted into blackened scars. Every breath tasted like ash and adrenaline.

He stepped in from the left, silhouette framed by fire. No blade. Just fury.

Arkady Volkov charged first, swinging a mop handle like a club.
Viktor sidestepped, grabbed a metal bench leg, and twirled it like a spear, slamming it into Arkadyâ€™s ribs.
Arkady doubled over. Viktor spun, kicked him in the chest, and sent him flying into a flaming stack of mats.

Mikhail â€œMishaâ€ Sokolov came next, trash lid raised like a shield.
Viktor vaulted off a locker, landed behind him, and delivered a spinning elbow to the spine.
Misha dropped the shield. Viktor grabbed it mid-fall and bashed his head three times each hit echoing like a war drum.

Yevgeny â€œZhenyaâ€ Morozov tried to flank him, fast and slippery.
Viktor caught a broken pipe, twirled it like a staff, and swept Zhenyaâ€™s legs.
He fell hard. Viktor flipped the pipe, jammed it under his chin, and lifted forcing Zhenya to stare into the fire before slamming him down.

Timofey â€œTimaâ€ Baranov, the coward, backed toward the bathroom door.

â€œYouâ€™re not gonna touch me,â€ he hissed. â€œYouâ€™re just a memory.â€

Viktor sprinted.


CRASH.
Tima flew through the door, shattered porcelain exploding around him.


Viktor stepped into the steam soaked chaos.
Tima scrambled to his feet, joined by the others bloodied, desperate, but not done.

Arkady lunged again. Viktor grabbed a towel rack, ripped it free, and hooked it behind Arkadyâ€™s neck, slamming him into the mirror.
Glass rained down. Arkady didnâ€™t rise.

Misha tackled him. Viktor twisted, flipped him over, and drove a knee into his chest.
He grabbed a sink pipe and cracked it across Mishaâ€™s jaw, sending him sprawling.

Zhenya tried to stab him with a shard. Viktor caught his wrist, snapped it, and threw him into a stall.
He kicked the toilet tank until it burst flooding the stall with boiling steam.

Tima crawled toward the exit.

Viktor followed.

He knelt beside him, mirror shard in hand.

â€œYou remember me now?â€

He didnâ€™t stab.

He pressed the shard into Timaâ€™s handâ€”a reflection, not a wound.

Then stood.

Silhouetted by fire.

Then came the ringing.

Shrill. Bone-deep.

A flash.

A hand on his shoulder.l



Awakening

He snapped awake.

Balcony. Night. Sweat. Silence.

The babushka knelt beside him, eyes wide.

â€œYou took too many,â€ she whispered. â€œThey donâ€™t just show you the past. They make you live it.â€

The gym was gone.

But his fists still throbbed like heâ€™d shattered bones.

The bowl beside him held only one Lie Berry left.



The Descent

The next morning, Viktor returned to the archive with the inspection team. Officers Ramosov and Morin led the sweep. Sample collection. Light scans. Infrared failures. Everything felt wrong.

Viktor wandered toward the back shelf.

Found the lever behind a warped panel.

Pulled it.

The floor cracked and collapsed.

He caught a steel beam mid-descent, boots kicking into void. Beneath him stretched a buried chamber crates, vents, stone walls sweating.

Above, his team scrambled to throw ropes.

One light popped.

Then another.

Then all.

Red emergency lighting flooded the chamber.

Smoke hissed from the ceiling. Dense. Synthetic. Alive.

Then movement.

It didnâ€™t walk.

It dropped.

The creature tore through the fog, limbs like bone tipped tendrils, body rippling in angles no spine should bend. Its central eye blazed molten gold and red. Not just seeing.

Knowing.

Ramosov screamed. A tendril wrapped around him and hurled him sideways. His spine cracked loud enough to echo.

Morin limped forward, one arm gone, gripping Viktorâ€™s sidearm. He reached Viktor, eyes wild not with terror.

With guilt.

Then the monster pierced him.

The weapon flew loose. It struck Viktorâ€™s head.

And Viktor fell.

Down into dust, blood, and ringing silence.

The Vault

He woke in the dark.

A terminal blinked in the corner.

Containment Subroutine 303 Delta ACTIVE
Status: Memory Breach
Subject: Viktor I.
Error: Identity Fragmentation Detected

He wasnâ€™t chasing a monster.

He was living inside its memory vault.

And now?

It knew who he really was.

(Tokyo, Japan â€“ Year 2025)

The world had changed quietly, without anyone truly realizing when it began.
It wasnâ€™t the internet, the machines, or even the endless wars â€” it was the light beneath the Earth.

Fifty years ago, scientists dug too deep beneath the Pacific. They called it Project Depthstar, the largest geological expedition ever attempted by humankind. The mission was meant to explore the planetâ€™s lower crust â€” but what they discovered was not rock, or lava. It was something that pulsed. Something alive.

When they drilled into it, the world changed forever.

A glowing liquid â€” the Aether Substance â€” surged from the fissure. It shimmered like starlight trapped in water, humming at a frequency that broke every sensor. Within minutes, it hardened into five massive shards, each the size of a car.

The scientists labeled them the Celestial Crystals.
Each shard radiated an energy field that could warp magnetism, light, even gravity. But within weeks, everyone exposed to it started to change. Some became stronger. Faster. Capable of impossible things.

Othersâ€¦ simply vanished.

The world governments shut it all down, sealing the truth. But they couldnâ€™t hide the side effects forever. Over the decades, trace particles of that same glowing matter spread into the air.

By 2025, a new generation of humans began awakening abilities â€” powers that defied reason. They called it Aether Affinity.

Those blessed with it became heroes, soldiers, or criminals.
And those without? They were forgotten.

Okay, here is a scary story for you: The old lighthouse stood sentinel against the jagged coastline, its beam a lonely finger slicing through the perpetual fog. Locals called it the Widow's Watch, a name earned from the countless wives who had watched their husbands sail away, never to return, their ships swallowed by the unforgiving sea. I, a marine biologist named Elias Thorne, had come to study the unusual bioluminescent algae blooms that thrived in the turbulent waters surrounding the lighthouse. I dismissed the local legends as superstition, the product of generations spent battling the elements. But the Widow's Watch had a way of making you question your convictions. The lighthouse keeper, a grizzled old man named Silas, was a man of few words. His face was a roadmap of wrinkles etched by wind and worry, his eyes as deep and gray as the ocean itself. He warned me about the "callers," the whispers that rode the wind, the shadows that danced in the periphery, the feeling of being watched even when alone. I chuckled, attributing it to the isolation and the constant drone of the foghorn. My research began uneventfully. I collected samples, analyzed data, and marveled at the ethereal glow of the algae blooms. But as the days turned into weeks, the unsettling feeling that Silas had described began to creep into my mind. It started subtly, a prickling sensation on the back of my neck, a fleeting glimpse of movement in the corner of my eye. Then came the whispers, carried on the wind, unintelligible murmurs that seemed to claw at the edges of my sanity. One night, as I worked late in the lamp room, the rhythmic sweep of the light suddenly faltered. The beam flickered erratically, casting grotesque shadows that writhed on the walls. The foghorn fell silent, plunging the lighthouse into an unnerving stillness. A cold dread washed over me, paralyzing me with fear. Then, I heard it â€“ a scraping sound, like nails dragging against stone, coming from the spiral staircase that wound its way down the lighthouse tower. It was slow, deliberate, and relentless, each scrape sending shivers down my spine. I grabbed a wrench, my hand trembling, and braced myself against the door, my heart pounding in my chest. The scraping grew louder, closer, until it was right outside the door. I could feel the vibrations through the wood, the palpable sense of something immense and malevolent on the other side. I held my breath, waiting for the inevitable. Suddenly, the scraping stopped. An eerie silence descended, broken only by the frantic beating of my own heart. Then, a voice, raspy and guttural, whispered from the other side of the door. "Eliasâ€¦" My blood ran cold. How did it know my name? I didn't answer, afraid to break the spell, afraid of what might happen if I acknowledged its presence. The voice whispered again, closer this time, its breath seeming to seep through the cracks in the door. "Eliasâ€¦ come homeâ€¦" The voice was hypnotic, alluring, promising something I couldn't quite grasp. I felt an irresistible urge to open the door, to succumb to its call, to step into the darkness and embrace whatever awaited me on the other side. But something held me back, a flicker of rationality, a desperate clinging to my sanity. I remembered Silas's warnings, the stories of the Widow's Watch, the countless souls lost to the sea. I knew that whatever was on the other side of that door was not of this world, that it was something ancient and malevolent, something that craved to consume me. I stumbled back from the door, knocking over a toolbox. The clang shattered the silence, breaking the spell. The voice hissed in anger, the scraping resumed, more frantic this time, as if whatever was on the other side was desperately trying to break through. I knew I had to escape. I scrambled to the window, ignoring the pleas of the voice, the relentless scraping at the door. I threw open the window, the icy wind whipping through the room, carrying with it the salty tang of the sea. Below me, the waves crashed against the rocks, a swirling vortex of foam and darkness. It was a long drop, but it was my only chance. I took a deep breath and jumped. The cold water shocked my system, stealing my breath. I plunged into the depths, the darkness closing in around me. I fought my way to the surface, gasping for air, the waves tossing me like a rag doll. I looked back at the lighthouse, its beam still flickering erratically, casting grotesque shadows on the fog. The scraping had stopped, but I could still feel its presence, watching me, waiting for me to return. I swam towards the shore, driven by a primal fear, the whispers of the "callers" chasing me through the waves. I finally reached the beach, collapsing on the sand, exhausted and terrified. I didn't stop running until I reached the town, my clothes soaked, my body trembling. I told the sheriff what had happened, but he dismissed it as a hallucination, the product of stress and isolation. I knew he didn't believe me, but I didn't care. I was alive, and that was all that mattered. I left the town the next morning, vowing never to return. But the Widow's Watch had left its mark on me. The whispers still haunted my dreams, the scraping still echoed in my ears. I knew that I would never truly escape the clutches of the lighthouse, that a part of me would always remain there, lost to the sea. Years later, I heard that Silas had disappeared. They found his boat adrift, with no sign of him. The locals whispered that the "callers" had finally claimed him, that he had succumbed to their allure and joined the countless souls lost to the Widow's Watch. Sometimes, late at night, when the wind is howling and the fog is thick, I hear the whispers again, carried on the wind, calling my name. And I know that one day, I will have to return to the Widow's Watch, to face the darkness that awaits me there, to finally answer the call of the sea.

For those who dont know: Circus peanuts are a curious and polarizing confection, notable for their bright orange color, spongy texture, and artificial banana flavor. Though often categorized as a â€œretroâ€ candy, circus peanuts have endured for more than a century in American culture. This document explores the origins, characteristics, production, and cultural significance of circus peanuts, along with their unusual role in candy history.

â¸»

2. Origins and History

The exact origin of circus peanuts is somewhat unclear, but they first gained popularity in the United States during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. These marshmallow candies were originally sold as a seasonal treat by traveling circuses and five-and-dime stores, often delivered in bulk barrels.

At the time, their appeal came from their novelty and affordability. Early versions were not standardized in flavor or color, but the bright orange hue and banana flavor soon became standardâ€”partly due to the limited variety of flavorings available and the low cost of artificial banana extract.

Circus peanuts became available year-round after the advent of packaging and better food preservation methods in the mid-20th century.

â¸»

3. Ingredients and Production

Despite their name, circus peanuts contain neither peanuts nor any nut-based ingredients. They are peanut-shaped for novelty purposes.

Typical ingredients include:
	â€¢	Sugar
	â€¢	Corn syrup
	â€¢	Gelatin
	â€¢	Artificial flavor (typically banana)
	â€¢	Food coloring (often FD&C Yellow #6 for the orange variety)

The candy is produced through a process similar to that used for marshmallows: the mixture is whipped, poured into peanut-shaped molds, and left to partially air-dry, creating their characteristic spongy-yet-dense texture.

â¸»

4. Flavor and Texture Profile

Circus peanuts are often described as having:
	â€¢	Texture: Chewy and airy, somewhat grainier and denser than standard marshmallows
	â€¢	Flavor: Artificial banana, reminiscent of banana Runts or old-fashioned medicine

These features make the candy divisive. While some enjoy its nostalgic charm and unique flavor, others find the taste and texture off-putting.

â¸»

5. Variations and Brand History

While the orange, banana-flavored version is most well-known, other versions have existed, including:
	â€¢	Pink (vanilla)
	â€¢	Yellow (lemon)
	â€¢	White (possibly wintergreen or unflavored)

However, the orange variety remains the most produced and recognized.

Major manufacturers include:
	â€¢	Spangler Candy Company â€“ One of the longest-standing producers, credited with keeping circus peanuts in circulation well into the 21st century.

â¸»

6. Legacy and Cultural Significance

Circus peanuts occupy a unique space in American candy culture. They are often cited in â€œworst candyâ€ rankings but retain a loyal niche fan base. Their long shelf life and distinct look have made them a common subject in nostalgic retrospectives and candy-themed pop culture media.

Interesting Fact: In the 1960s, a food scientist experimenting with chopped circus peanuts and gelatin created what eventually became Lucky Charms cerealâ€”one of the first cereals to include marshmallow bits (or â€œmarbitsâ€).

â¸»

7. Criticism and Decline

With changing tastes and a rise in consumer demand for natural flavors and less processed treats, circus peanuts have declined in popularity. Many modern consumers associate them with outdated or stale candy offerings. Nonetheless, they continue to be produced and sold, particularly in retro-themed candy stores and online.

â¸»



Circus peanuts are a resilient relic of a bygone era in American candy-makingâ€”bizarre, beloved by a few, reviled by others, and unmistakably iconic. Whether as a nostalgic snack or a curiosity for the adventurous sweet tooth, circus peanuts remain a quirky staple of the confectionery landscape.

â¸»

Appendix A: Nutritional Information (Typical per serving of ~6 pieces)
	â€¢	Calories: ~140
	â€¢	Total Fat: 0g
	â€¢	Sodium: 35mg
	â€¢	Total Carbohydrate: 36g
	â€¢	Sugars: 29g
	â€¢	Protein: 1g

*The 8th Floor*

Dr. Aris Thorne worked late. Always late. His genetics lab occupied the sterile, humming 7th floor of the Kronos Biotech Tower â€“ a monument to glass, steel, and relentless progress. Tonight, exhaustion blurred the fluorescent lines of the hallway as he finally packed up. The digital clock above the elevator glowed **2:17 AM**.

He pressed the call button. The usual soft chime echoed, but the descent feltâ€¦ heavier. The car arrived with a groan that wasn't part of its usual repertoire. Inside, the polished steel walls seemed duller, the air thick and stale, smelling faintly of ozone and damp concrete. He pressed â€˜Gâ€™ for the ground floor lobby.

The descent began smoothly, then jolted. The lights flickered violently, plunging Aris into utter darkness for three heart-stopping seconds before returning, dimmer now, casting long, trembling shadows. The digital display above the door froze: **8**.

Aris frowned. Kronos Tower only had seven floors. Everyone knew that. Floor 8 was a myth, a ghost story whispered by interns after too much coffee â€“ a bureaucratic error in the blueprints, a space never built, sealed off.

The elevator stopped with a final, bone-rattling clang. The doors didnâ€™t open. Aris mashed the â€˜Door Openâ€™ button. Nothing. He pressed â€˜Gâ€™ again, then â€˜7â€™. The buttons lit up dully but the elevator remained inert. Panic, cold and slick, began to crawl up his spine. He hammered on the doors. "Hello? Anyone? Malfunction!"

Silence. Thick, oppressive, listening silence. Then, a sound. Faint at first, like dry leaves skittering across stone. It grew closer, resolving into a chorus of hushed, frantic *whispers*. They seemed to come from all around him, from the very walls of the elevator car, overlapping and unintelligible, yet filled with an unmistakable edge of terror and warning.

"...wrong floor..."  
"...shouldn't be here..."  
"...never existed..."  
"...get out...get out...GET OUT..."

Aris backed into a corner, his breath coming in ragged gasps. The whispers intensified, becoming more desperate, almost weeping. He covered his ears, but the sound wormed its way in, vibrating in his skull.

Suddenly, the elevator lights died completely. Utter, suffocating blackness. The whispers stopped. In the absolute void, Aris could hear only his own frantic heartbeat andâ€¦ something else. A slow, wet, dragging sound. Like something heavy, wrapped in sodden cloth, being pulled across the floorâ€¦ outside the elevator doors.

Thumpâ€¦ scrapeâ€¦ thumpâ€¦ scrapeâ€¦

It stopped right in front of the doors. Aris froze, sweat chilling on his brow. He could feel a presence, vast and impossibly cold, radiating through the steel. A faint, greenish light began to seep under the elevator doors â€“ a sickly, unnatural glow that illuminated nothing but the thin gap.

Then, a single, guttural sound came from the other side, not a word, but a vibration that shook the floor beneath his feet: *"MÌ¶ÍÌŠÌ•Ì¹IÌ¸Ì‡Ì½ÌŠÍNÌ·Ì’Ì EÌµÌ¿ÌÌÌ©Ì—."*

The elevator jolted violently upwards. The lights snapped back on, blindingly bright. The digital display whirred: *7... 6... 5...* Aris collapsed against the wall, trembling uncontrollably.

The doors slid open smoothly onto the pristine, brightly lit lobby. The night security guard looked up from his desk, frowning. "Dr. Thorne? You okay? You look like you've seen a ghost."

Aris stumbled out, unable to speak, his eyes fixed on the elevator panel. The button for Floor 8 was gone. In its place was smooth, unmarked steel, as if it had never existed.

He never worked late again. But sometimes, alone in his 7th-floor lab late at night, he'd hear it â€“ a faint, distant thumpâ€¦ scrapeâ€¦ from the elevator shaft. And heâ€™d remember the suffocating dark, the desperate whispers, and the chilling, possessive hunger in that single, impossible word echoing from the floor that shouldnâ€™t be. He knew, with cold certainty, that the 8th floor was real. And it was waiting.

There was a small village nestled at the edge of a dark, thick forest. The villagers often warned their children to stay away from the woods, especially after dusk. But young Ellie, who loved adventure, didnâ€™t always listen.

One evening, just as the sun was setting and the sky turned a deep orange, Ellie decided to explore the forest. Her grandmother had told her stories of a hidden, magical clearing deep within the trees, where the light always danced in strange patterns, and flowers grew that never wilted. Ellie was curious. Maybe she could find this place herself!

With a small backpack and a flashlight, Ellie slipped out of her house and walked into the woods. The trees towered above her, their leaves rustling in the breeze. It was quiet at first, but as she went deeper, the air felt heavier, colder. She pulled her jacket tighter around her shoulders and pressed on.

Suddenly, Ellie noticed something odd. The trees had begun to look twisted, their branches reaching out like long, bony fingers. The path she had been following seemed to vanish, swallowed by the dark shadows around her. Ellie felt a chill run down her spine, but she convinced herself it was nothing. After all, she was brave, just like the heroes in her favorite stories.

Then, she heard itâ€”a faint whisper. It wasnâ€™t the wind; it was a voice. â€œEllieâ€¦ come closer.â€

Her heart raced. She turned around, shining the flashlight in all directions, but there was nothing. The forest felt alive, watching her every move.

Ellie took a deep breath, trying to shake off the fear. She continued walking, but the whisper grew louder, â€œEllieâ€¦ we are waiting.â€ The voice seemed to echo from everywhere at once.

Just then, she stumbled upon a small clearing. At first, it seemed peaceful, but the moment she stepped inside, the air turned ice cold. The trees surrounding the clearing seemed to shift, blocking her exit. The ground beneath her feet began to crack and twist, like the earth itself was alive. In the center of the clearing, there was an old, gnarled tree with a hollow at its base.

A soft, glowing light pulsed from inside the hollow. Ellie felt both drawn to it and terrified at the same time. â€œEllie, come closer,â€ the voice urged again, now soft and sweet. Without thinking, Ellie stepped forward, reaching for the light.

But as her hand got closer, the light flickered. The hollow of the tree began to widen, and out of it slithered something dark and shadowy, with glowing red eyes. It hissed, a low, bone-chilling sound that made Ellie freeze in place.

Before she could run, the ground beneath her feet gave way, and she fell. The shadows reached up, grabbing her ankles. The whisper turned to a roar, â€œStay with us, Ellie!â€ The shadows wrapped around her, pulling her deeper into the earth, until everything went dark.

The next morning, the villagers found Ellieâ€™s backpack by the edge of the forest. But there was no sign of her.

From that day on, when the wind howls through the trees, you can hear a faint whisper: â€œEllieâ€¦ come play with us.â€ And if you listen too closely, you might just hear her voice answering back from the shadows.

In an isolated cabin deep in the woods, a group of friends gathered for a weekend getaway. One night, they decided to tell ghost stories by the fire. As the tales grew darker, the wind howled outside, rattling the windows. Suddenly, they heard a loud thump from the attic. Curious and a bit frightened, they decided to investigate. As they climbed the creaky stairs, a sense of dread filled the air. In the attic, they discovered an old trunk covered in dust. When they opened it, they found a collection of faded photographs of previous occupants. In each photo, a shadowy figure lurked in the background, growing clearer with each image. Realizing they were not alone, panic set in. They rushed down the stairs, but the door slammed shut, trapping them inside. The lights flickered, and whispers filled the room, growing louder, urging them to stay. As the friends huddled together, the shadowy figure appeared, grinning menacingly. One by one, they vanished, their screams echoing in the night. The next morning, the cabin stood silent, but if you look closely, you might see their faces in the photographsâ€”forever part of the haunted history. Would you dare to spend a night in that cabin?

The FNAF lore is complex and multifaceted. Hereâ€™s a brief summary:

The Five Nights at Freddyâ€™s (FNAF) series revolves around a fictional family restaurant called Freddy Fazbearâ€™s Pizza, where animatronic characters, originally designed for children, harbor dark secrets. The central conflict involves the murders of children by a former employee, William Afton, who uses the animatronics to manipulate the souls of the deceased.

The story unfolds across various games, where players take on the role of night security guards trying to survive encounters with the animatronics while uncovering the restaurantâ€™s dark history. Themes of grief, revenge, and the quest for justice run throughout the series.

The mythology also explores the Afton family, particularly the tragic fates of Williamâ€™s children and the repercussions of his actions. The narratives are often non-linear and filled with hidden clues for fans to analyze.

Later entries, such as FNAF: Security Breach, expand the story with new characters and a larger setting. Despite the diversity of the games, the core theme remains the eerie connection between humans and machines, as well as the ghosts of the past.

This summary only scratches the surface, as FNAF lore is rich with mysteries and theories continually explored by the fan community.

Late one night, Jack was home alone when he heard his wife calling his name from the kitchen. Confused, he checked his phone and saw a missed call from her. He called back, and she answered immediately, sounding frantic.

"Jack, listen to me," she said. "I'm still at my parents' house, miles away. Don't go into the kitchen. I don't know who or what that is, but it's not me."

Jack's heart pounded as he heard the voice from the kitchen again, louder and more insistent. Summoning his courage, he grabbed a knife and crept towards the kitchen door. Just as he reached it, the voice stopped. The kitchen was empty.

He backed away, his phone still pressed to his ear. "Jack," his wife whispered through the phone, "it's right behind you."

He turned around slowly, but there was nothing there. Yet the whispering continued, echoing through the empty house.

So lemme tell you something, this is not fake, Iâ€™ve been in this situationâ€¦

Last night, as I diligently worked on my homework, the soft glow of my Chromebook screen illuminated my quiet room. My fingers danced across the keyboard, eyes fixed on the assignment, fully immersed in the task at hand. It was a typical evening, filled with the familiar rhythm of study.

Suddenly, a subtle flicker caught the very edge of my vision. It was gone almost as quickly as it appeared, a fleeting disturbance in the periphery. I paused, my concentration momentarily broken, and glanced around the room. Nothing. Convinced it was just my imagination, perhaps a trick of the light or an exhausted blink, I returned to my work, trying to recapture my focus. 

But then, it happened again. That same elusive flicker, a brief yet undeniable movement at the corner of my eye. This time, a shiver ran down my spine. It was too distinct to ignore, too precise to be a mere optical illusion. My heart began to beat a little faster, and a prickle of unease settled over me.

The quiet hum of my Chromebook was the only sound echoing in my room last night as I wrestled with a particularly tricky math problem. My textbooks lay scattered around me like fallen soldiers in a losing battle, and the soft glow of the screen cast long shadows that danced with every subtle shift of my posture. I was deep in the labyrinth of quadratic equations, determined to conquer them before the night was through.

It was then, in a moment of intense concentration, that I felt itâ€”a subtle disruption at the very edge of my vision. A flicker, quick and elusive, like a butterfly wing brushing past. I dismissed it, attributing it to fatigue or the play of shadows, and dove back into the numbers, trying to recall the formula for the vertex of a parabola. My brain, however, had already registered the anomaly.

Just as I thought I had a breakthrough with the equation, the flicker returned. This time, it was more defined, a fleeting, almost transparent ripple in the air that seemed to originate from the corner of my room. My breath hitched, and the hairs on my arms rose. It wasn't my imagination; something was there, just beyond the scope of my direct gaze, watching. And it was waiting for me to acknowledge it.

âš ï¸TRUE STORY!âš ï¸ Here's some popcorn because I will tell everything that happend ğŸ¿. (In parts)




It was morning and it was the day when my cousin (she is a girl) and my bestie came to my grandparents's house! I slept at my grandparents because they had a party for 2 days and today the day 2 started (my parents and their parents were there also.) I hugged them and we decided to play upstairs. We went there because we had more toys and also wanted to sleep upstairs at the night. We had two beds (one for me and my cousin and one for my bestie) but we moved the beds close to eachother (let's say sticked the beds). Then we started playing with some plushies. The night came and me and my cousin's grandma came and said "Time to sleep, goodnight!" And we said "Goodnight grandma!" (My bestie also calls her grandma). Ok back to the story we went to sleep and at 00:00 am my bestie woke us up and I said "What is it?" And she said "I heard some steps from the garden.. I don't maybe it was my imagination?" But I said "Yea it was.. I guess?" So my cousin was speechless and I asked "What's wrong?" "Nothing, but I don't think she was the only one who heard the steps.." "Oh really, did u?" "Yea!" So I took a look behind the curtains and there was first a balcony so I said "Come on, I am scared to check so someone come with me!" And my bestie came with me on the balcony and my cousin stood in the cozy bed and she was shaking. Now behind the balcony there was my grandparent's garden and we looked and there was no one? And I told my cousin "Don't worry, there's no one! Maybe it was our neighbour?" But I thought why would our neighbour would go out at 00:20 am (It took 20 minutes to talk and check so yeah) but I said "What you two heard definetely wasn't in our garden." So we went back to sleep and at 00:40 my cousin woke us up and she told us that she heard a scratch in the room next to our upstairs room so I said "Ugh I will check again" so I went and in the other room there was just our kitten, Oreo. So I brought him in the room and told my cousin "There was no one just this naughty little kitten, Oreo! Our grandpa definetely forgot him in the house. Now come on it's late let's get back to sleep and also if you're scared again you can just hold Oreo." And we let the kitten to sleep on our blanket.

Hereâ€™s a well-documented real story of a lost child with a dramatic, bittersweet resolutionâ€”rooted in 20th-century Philippine history, close to your location in Central Luzon:
 
The Case of Carlito "Lito" Lapid (1972, Pampanga)
 
In 1972, 5-year-old Carlito "Lito" Lapid (no relation to the Filipino actor of the same name) vanished while playing outside his familyâ€™s nipa hut in Barangay San Isidro, Bacolor, Pampanga. His mother, Maria, had stepped inside to fetch water for a few minutes; when she returned, Lito was gone, with only his tattered rubber slipper left by a nearby rice field.
 
1.Â Community search and initial despair: The entire barangay mobilized to searchâ€”farmers combed rice paddies, fishermen checked nearby rivers, and local police set up roadblocks. Maria, a single mother working as a laundry maid, distributed hand-drawn flyers across Central Luzon, but no leads emerged for three months. Rumors spread: some said Lito was abducted by a child trafficker, others claimed heâ€™d fallen into a hidden irrigation tunnel.
2.Â A chance discovery during a typhoon: In October 1972, Typhoon Gloring (one of the strongest storms to hit Pampanga that decade) caused massive flooding, washing away parts of a disused sugar mill warehouse on the outskirts of Bacolor. A group of rescue workers clearing debris found a small, emaciated boy huddled in a locked storage closet, clutching a tattered toy car Litoâ€™s mother had given him.
3.Â The shocking truth: The boy was Lito. Heâ€™d been lured into the warehouse by a local man whoâ€™d recently lost his own child; the man had locked him up, leaving small amounts of rice and water daily but never speaking to him. The man had died in a drunk-driving accident two weeks before the typhoon, leaving Lito trapped with no way out.
4.Â Aftermath: Lito survived but struggled with severe traumaâ€”he refused to speak for a year and feared enclosed spaces. With the help of local church counselors and his motherâ€™s unwavering care, he gradually recovered. As an adult, he became a volunteer with Pampangaâ€™s missing childrenâ€™s advocacy groups, helping reunite other lost kids with their families until his death in 2020.
 
This story is documented in Pampangaâ€™s provincial archives and local news clippings from the 1970s, and itâ€™s still cited by local advocacy groups to highlight the importance of community vigilance for child safety.

I thought I heard someone say something, but I thought I was paranoid. Then there was an ear-piercing place I saw in the abandoned mall too. I got worried and thought I was paranoid again until I saw the escalator moving, and someone at the bottom. LITERALLY. 'Hello?..' Here's a story! :D (this isn't real!)


     Charlie was just getting off the bus, now walking home from school. It was oddly quiet, most kids weren't at school that day though. It was cold and windy, and only a couple cars passed by. But when they did pass, they were fast. As if they were in a hurry.

     When Charlie got home her mom wasn't there like usual. Maybe she's just at the grocery store? Charlie's brother, Austin was home though. He didn't really say anything, just a hi. Charlie started working on her homework in her room when she heard the front door open. It's her mom! But she's different Charlie's mom didn't have that look she usually had, her mom had this tired look as if she never slept and she was also unusually calm.
     "Mom you good-? You look tired..." Charlie asked. "Yeah yeah, I'm good sweetie.." Her mom doesn't call people sweetie "Um.. Okay- Where'd you go anyways?"
"Oh I just forgot some stuff at work, I had to go get them." Charlie's mom said nervously. 
     Charlie went off to her room to go finish that homework she started before mom came. scratch scratch "What was that...?" Charlie looked at her window, where the sound was coming from. She saw a figure standing out there. It stood tall, not making a sound. It then disappeared into thin air.. She stood there shaking, not knowing what just happened. Maybe she just needs rest..?
     She went to bed, she's probably just tired. In Charlie's dream she's in a room, it's dark and she can hear a faint scratching sound, but it's hard to locate where it's coming from.. Suddenly the same figure shows in her dream. It has a gun.. It points it at her and when it pulls the trigger she wakes up, sweating. "What the heck..."

Chapter 1 â€” The House She Shouldâ€™ve Never Inherited
When Lenaâ€™s grandmother died, the old mansion on the edge of town became hers.
People whispered that the house had a pulse, that it â€œbreathedâ€ when you were alone.
But Lena didnâ€™t believe in ghosts. She believed in proof.
The house was three stories high, its roof caved in from years of storms.
Every step she took echoed through hollow halls.
The air smelled like dust, lavenderâ€¦ and something rotten underneath.
In the upstairs corridor stood a tall mirror, shrouded in a black sheet.
Words were carved into the wood:
â€œDo not uncover what remembers.â€
Lena ran her fingers over the engraving. â€œCreepy,â€ she muttered, forcing a smile.
But that night, she dreamed of a woman standing where the mirror was â€” whispering her name.
Chapter 2 â€” The Footsteps
The next morning, Lena woke to the faint sound of footsteps.
They came from the hallway, slow and dragging.
When she opened her door, no one was there.
Only wet footprints, small and bare, leading to the covered mirror.
She stared at them.
They stopped right in front of the mirror â€” and vanished.
By afternoon, she tried laughing it off. Maybe an animal got in.
But that night, she dreamed again â€” the same woman whispering,
â€œYou look just like herâ€¦â€
When Lena asked, â€œWho?â€
The womanâ€™s head twisted at an unnatural angle, and the dream shattered into darkness.
Chapter 3 â€” The Whisper
On the third night, it started speaking.
A faint voice from behind the covered mirror:
â€œLenaâ€¦ do you remember me?â€
Her heart nearly stopped. She stumbled back, grabbing her phone, but the screen flickered â€” dead.
Then, faintly, another whisper:
â€œYou used to stand here. Every night. You used to smile.â€
The next morning, she searched through her grandmotherâ€™s journals.
Most were recipes, prayersâ€¦ and one short entry, written shakily:
â€œThe mirror knows her face. I should have broken it years ago.
If I die, tell Lena never to uncover it.â€
She dropped the book.
Her grandmother knew. She warned her.
But against every instinct, Lena felt drawn to it â€” like the glass was calling her name in her bloodstream.
Chapter 4 â€” The Unveiling
The fourth night was storming hard.
Thunder rolled. The house trembled.
The whispers came again â€” louder this time, desperate.
â€œLena, please. I canâ€™t see. Take the cover off.â€
Her hands shook.
Lightning flashed outside, and for a moment, she saw a faint shadow moving under the sheet â€” like something pressing its face against the fabric from the other side.
She yanked the cover down.
The glass was cracked and fogged, but her reflection was there â€” wide-eyed, trembling.
Then it blinked.
Once.
Twice.
Out of sync with her.
Lena gasped and stumbled back.
Her reflection smiled. A slow, wrong, human smile that stretched far too wide.
It lifted its hand and tapped the inside of the mirror.
A muffled sound â€” like knuckles against glass.
â€œFinally,â€ it whispered.
â€œYou remember me now.â€
Chapter 5 â€” The Memory
Lena backed away, whispering â€œNoâ€¦ noâ€¦â€
The reflection stepped forward â€” but she didnâ€™t move.
It was walking toward her, from inside the mirror.
Suddenly, the glass rippled like water. The air turned cold enough to sting.
Flashes of faces appeared in the reflection â€” dozens of them â€” crying, screaming, trapped.
â€œShe kept us here,â€ the voice said, but it was coming from behind Lena now.
â€œYour grandmother. She took us inâ€¦ through the mirror.â€
Lena turned, and the woman from her dreams stood there â€” pale, hollow-eyed, her mouth stitched at the corners.
The stitches snapped open as she whispered,
â€œNow itâ€™s your turn to remember.â€
Hands â€” cold, glassy hands â€” reached out from the mirror and dragged Lena forward.
She screamed, clawing at the floor, but the wood cracked beneath her nails.
Her reflection smiled one last time before pulling her inside.
The mirror went still.
Chapter 6 â€” What the Neighbors Heard
When the storm ended, the house was silent again.
Neighbors said they heard someone screaming during the night, but no one came out.
When police arrived two days later, they found the front door open and the halls empty.
Only one thing had changed.
The black sheet was gone.
And in the tall, uncovered mirror stood Lena â€” smiling faintly, her hand pressed against the glass.
If you look close enough, you can still see her eyes move.
And if you stand there long enough,
youâ€™ll hear her whisper â€” soft as breath:
â€œDo you remember me?â€

On her third night, Aira heard it â€” a soft whisper from behind that same door.
â€œAiraâ€¦ let me out.â€
She froze. The voice was faint, tremblingâ€¦ like someone crying.

â€œPlease, Airaâ€¦ itâ€™s so dark in hereâ€¦â€
Her heart pounded. She placed her ear against the wood â€” and something knocked back. Three slow knocks.
The next morning, she searched the house for a key but found none. Still, the curiosity grew like a sickness. On the fifth night, she couldnâ€™t resist anymore. She grabbed a screwdriver and forced the door open.
The room was empty â€” dust everywhere. Except for a mirror standing in the middle.
In the reflection, she saw herselfâ€¦ and behind her, a pale figure smiling.
The door slammed shut. The whisper turned into laughter â€” low and broken.
Now, if you walk past that old house, you can still hear her voice behind the same door saying,
â€œPleaseâ€¦ let me outâ€¦â€

True story Something scary happened. I was home alone one night when I heard a loud banging coming from the basement. My heart started racing as I slowly made my way down the stairs, the only source of light coming from my phone's flashlight. The banging grew louder and more frantic with each step I took. As I reached the bottom of the stairs, I saw the basement door violently shaking as if someone or something was trying to break through. I stood frozen in fear, not knowing what to do. And that's when I heard a voice whisper my name from the other side of the door...

Part 2 super scary... was when the lights suddenly went out, plunging the room into complete darkness. The sound of heavy footsteps could be heard approaching, getting louder and louder with each passing second. I could feel my heart pounding in my chest as I tried to control my breathing and remain as still as possible. Suddenly, a cold hand grabbed my shoulder, causing me to scream in terror. I turned around to see a figure standing in front of me, their face shrouded in darkness. As they reached out towards me, I closed my eyes and braced myself for the worst...

Part 3 super super scary... was the haunted house at the end of the street. The rumors surrounding the old abandoned mansion were enough to send shivers down anyone's spine. Stories of ghostly figures appearing in the windows at night, strange noises coming from within its walls, and a chilling presence that could be felt by anyone who dared to get too close. Despite the warnings from the townspeople, a group of brave teenagers decided to investigate the house one dark and stormy night. As they approached the creaky front door, they could feel the hairs on the back of their necks standing on end. The door swung open with a loud groan, revealing a pitch-black interior that seemed to swallow up any trace of light. With trembling hands, they stepped inside, their hearts pounding in their chests. Little did they know, they were about to uncover the terrifying truth behind the haunted house...

Being only 10 or so during the time we thought nothing would happen but oh were we wrong... so we went in i had my bb gun that i had just got and the rest had sticks, we got deeper and deeper in the forest and heard it, it was a deep scratching noise sounding like it come off a metal chunk, but we didnt remember seeing anything metal in the woods, so we investigated and we found a little bunker, being stupid we dared albert to go in by himself and when he eventually agreed we shut him in, at first everything was fine but. Then we heard it a shrieking coming from inside... and it wasnt albert.... he screamed for us to open to door but it wouldnt budge and that was the last we heard of him we decided to run home and get our fathers cause they were over for dinner so we got out of the forest and i looked back and saw it a tall pale creature with boney features, it seemed although it was wearing alberts face and smiling at us. In the morning our fathers called the cops and helped them look. When they found the bunker it was indeed to late. Alberts body lay frozen in the ground and faceless... its good to say that we never forgot albert and didnt go deep into those forests ever again."

One day I was at the park near my house and there I saw a little girl sitting alone,suddenly she looked at me and said HI I thought that maybe she has no friends so.....I went near her and said back HI she just smiles and took out a doll from her bag I thought she was giving it to me but she gave it to my little sister I thought maybe I'm too old to be her friend and maybe my sister was the same age as her so my sister said 'AWW THANK YOU SO MUCH' after that the girl went away and we also came back home ğŸ  after that we ate our dinner and went to sleep but in the middle of the night ğŸŒƒ I heard someone singing in the hallway I checked outside and saw my little sister singing I looked at the clock it was 2am so I told my sister that 'what are you doing so late' I noticed that she was holding that doll then I said'what are you doing so late?' she didn't answer she just went back to her room and I went back to my bed too just 1 hour later at 3am I heard someone laughing I ran to my sister's room and saw........her talking to the doll I quietly slied on her she took a KNIFE and cut the doll's head I was just wondering what she was doing then suddenly she looked at me I quickly locked her room and ran to my parent's room I woke then up and told them what was going on with her my parent's believed me as I never told a lie so we checked on her again we saw now the doll was cut into pieces and my sister was screaming like a psycho and just then she took the KNIFE again and came running to us we tam as fast as we could my mother went to our neighbour my dad went to his car but I.....went to my sister's room and took all the pieces of the doll and burnt it I went running to my mom and dad then we went to my sister she was lying on the floor we took her to her room and in the next morning I checked on her she was OK then we told her what happened to her and she was shocked.......


I still wonder who was that little girl in the park and why did she gave that doll to my sister ğŸ˜¢ğŸ˜®

When it was her birthday again, no one was there because her family died by a brown bear, but she would not find them, so now she would make breakfast, dinner, and cakes for her birthday by herself. every day a new family moves to the cul-de-sac, let alone one that moves in at three in the morning. Still, when the moving van pulled up to the dilapidated house at the end of the street, the flickering porch light the only welcome sign, the neighbors all pretended not to notice. From his bedroom window, nine-year-old Finn watched the figures, shrouded in darkness and haste, unload a single, oversized, black cabinet. It seemed out of place, an ancient relic in a sea of modern suburbia, and as they struggled to carry it into the house, Finn swore he saw the wooden doors of the cabinet bulge outward as if something from inside were pushing to be let out.
The next day, a girl Finnâ€™s age, her hair as black as the cabinet and her face pale as bone, introduced herself as Lily. Her parents were reclusive and unfriendly, a stark contrast to the neighborhoodâ€™s usual cheerful, outgoing residents. Lily spoke in a whisper, her eyes wide and dark, like two endless pits. â€œWeâ€™re not staying long,â€ she murmured when Finn asked about her family. â€œFather says itâ€™s just for a visit.â€ But a visit to whom, Finn wondered. He glanced toward Lilyâ€™s house, and through the dust-streaked window, he could just make out the shape of the large black cabinet, now placed ominously in the center of their living room.
The oddities began subtly. Mrs. Gable, the streetâ€™s gossipy matriarch, complained that her prize-winning rose bushes were wilting overnight, the petals turning black and shriveled. Mr. Henderson, a man of routine, swore his late-night dog walk was being watched by a pair of glowing red eyes from the window of Lilyâ€™s house. No one believed him, of course, dismissing it as the ramblings of an old man with a vivid imagination. But Finn knew better. He had also seen the lightâ€”a faint, unsettling crimson pulse emanating from the window of Lilyâ€™s living room.
One evening, Lily appeared at Finnâ€™s doorstep, her whisper more urgent than usual. â€œHeâ€™s restless,â€ she hissed, her eyes darting nervously back to her house. â€œMy father tried to calm it, but it didn't work.â€ Finnâ€™s blood ran cold. The cabinet. He thought of the bulge, the frantic pressure against the wood. What kind of thing could cause such unease? He asked her what was inside. Lily only shook her head, a tear tracing a path through the grime on her cheek. â€œDonâ€™t ask,â€ she pleaded. â€œJustâ€¦ donâ€™t go near the house after dark.â€
But curiosity, a far more powerful emotion than fear for a nine-year-old, drove Finn back to his window. He watched as Lilyâ€™s parents hurried inside, their movements stiff and hurried, and the porch light flickered and died for good. A low, rhythmic thumping, like a slow, heavy heartbeat, began to pulse from their house. It vibrated through the quiet evening air, a deep, resonant sound that seemed to shake the very foundations of Finnâ€™s home. He held his breath, pressing his face against the glass.
The thumping grew faster, louder, more frantic. Finn could see Lilyâ€™s father standing before the cabinet now, his back to the window. His shoulders began to shake, his movements growing more spastic and uncontrolled. He seemed to be struggling with something unseen. The thumping ceased, replaced by a low, guttural growl that seemed to vibrate the very air. Finnâ€™s hand flew to his mouth, stifling a terrified gasp.
Suddenly, Lilyâ€™s father stumbled back, and his wife rushed to his side. They both stared at the cabinet, their faces etched with pure terror. Finn watched in horror as the giant cabinet doors slowly creaked open, revealing not a shelf-lined interior but a swirling, inky darkness. It was a hungry, endless void, and from within, a single, glowing red eye opened, fixing its gaze directly on Finnâ€™s window.
The night air, once filled with the rhythmic thumping, was now deathly silent. Finn felt a chill deeper than the evening air settle into his bones. His mind raced, replaying the awful scene. The fear on the parentsâ€™ faces. The endless darkness within the cabinet. The single, malevolent eye. He crept away from the window, pulling the curtains tightly shut, as if the thin fabric could shield him from the horror he had just witnessed.
A new sound began. It was a soft, methodical tap, tap, tapping, coming from the window of Lilyâ€™s house, now perfectly illuminated by a full moon. Finn froze, his heart pounding in his chest. It was a deliberate, insistent rhythm, like knuckles on glass. It was a familiar sound, one that had been heard before but dismissed. Mr. Henderson had heard it, only his was a dog walker being watched. But now, it was clearer, more focused.
Finn squeezed his eyes shut, trying to block out the image of the cabinet, the void, and the hungry, endless darkness inside. But the tapping continued, and a new, terrible thought dawned on him. Lily had said her father had tried to calm it. What was "it"? And why was it now looking at his house?
His blood ran cold as he remembered Lilyâ€™s final, terrified words: â€œHeâ€™s restless.â€ And in that moment, Finn realized the tapping wasnâ€™t just a sound; it was a beckoning. But our favorite thing was the ghost. We called her Mother, because she seemed so kind and nurturing. Some mornings Betsy and I would wake up, and on each of our nightstands, weâ€™d find a cup that hadnâ€™t been there the night before. Mother had left them there, worried that weâ€™d get thirsty during the night. She just wanted to take care of us. Among the homesâ€™ original furnishings was an antique wooden chair which we kept against the back wall of the living room. Whenever we were preoccupied, watching TV or playing a game, Mother would inch that chair forward, across the room, toward us. Sometimes sheâ€™d manage to move it all the way to the centre of the room. We always felt sad putting it back against the wall. Mother just wanted to be near us. Years later, long after weâ€™d moved out, I found an old newspaper article about the farmhouseâ€™s original occupant, a widow. Sheâ€™d murdered her two children by giving them each a cup of poisoned milk before bed. Then she hung herself. The article included a photo of the farmhouseâ€™s living room, with a womanâ€™s body hanging from a beam. Beneath her, knocked over, was that old wooden chair, placed exactly in the center of the room.â€

Freddy backed away, his heart beating a marathon, sweat poured down into his eyes, Jesus Christ he was scared! 
Freddy ran as if he had never ran before, his shirt flapped in the wind like a ship raising its sails in a tornado, speaking of which, Freddy couldnâ€™t think straight, his emotions had been swept away, clean out of his mind. Thatâ€™s when he heard it.

Not footsteps. Not breathing. A dragging sound. Slow. Wet. Like something pulling itself along the ground, refusing to be left behind.

Freddyâ€™s legs burned, but the sound didnâ€™t fade. It was closer nowâ€”scraping against the tarmac, nails or claws or something worse.

He risked a glance over his shoulder.

The man wasnâ€™t running. He was standing. And yet, somehow, the distance between them was shrinking.

The streetlights above flickered, one by one, as Freddy tore past them. Shadows stretched unnaturally long, reaching for his ankles. His lungs screamed for air, but the dragging sound was in his ears now, inside his head, matching the rhythm of his heartbeat.

Thenâ€”silence.

Freddy slowed, chest heaving, eyes darting. The road ahead was empty. The air was still.

And from right behind him, a voice whispered, low and cold: "You shouldnâ€™t have run." Freddy whipped around, only to be met with nothing. He looked up; it was dark. Freddy saw something else, though... In the corner of his eye he was met with, atop a large grey building, a pair of eyes looking down at him, Freddy felt his knees begin to shake uncontrollably, his pants flapping like flags, Freddy felt heavy rainfall hit him, he heard the constant pitter-patter of rain hitting the floor, but he never looked at it, for he was looking at the pair of eyes towering above himâ€¦ Wind pushed the rain into Freddyâ€™s eyes, and he yelped in pain, toppling over to the floor, wiping his eyes, â€œUh ohâ€¦â€  He thought fearfully, hoping he was wrong, he opened his eyes, and he was right. The silhouette rushed past him as if a trick of the light, but Freddy saw the eyes were gone and he knewâ€¦ that the man was right behind him.

It was 4am at night. A girl called MIA was sleeping. She heard footsteps, Glasses breaking, And music playing in the kitchen. Mia didnt want to go into the kitchen because she was obviously scared of the dark. She decided to Use a flashlight and check it out. Went she turned her flashlight on and went into the kitchen, There was a girl, That looked just like her, Dancing on the kitchen table. Mia screamed. "WHO ARE YOU?????" The girl stared at Mia. "Im you." Mia screamed loudly. Her mom woke up and ran into the kitchen. "Sweetie- WHO IS THIS?" Mia turned to her mom. She shrugged. "I dont know, Kick her out!" The girl stared at them. She laughed. "No, i live here." Mia Giggled. "No, We live here. Only us." The girl Screamed. "My mom said nobody else lives here." Mia and mias mom Pushes her off the table. "Stop lying, You Spy." They kicked the girl out. They went to sleep. The next day, Mias mom was making breakfast. She was still dreaming and thinking about Last nights incident. Wow. What a night. It was scary. 

Part 2. 
Mia woke up. Eyes Half open, still yawning, And has a headache. She starts to strech. She leaves her room and sighs. "Hey mom, good morning." Mias mom turns to her. "Good morning, Hun." Mia laughs. She sits down and starts to eat her breakfast. She yawns and drinks water. "Thanks." "Welcome, Hun." Someone knocks on the door. It's the delivery man. Delivering a Amazon package. "Uh....I didnt order anything?" 
The delivery guy stares. "This is for...Mia adams...." "Wait... But.... I didnt order anything." Mias mom turns to Mia. "Did you sneak on my computer and order something? Cause if you did Your getting grounded." Mia Giggles. "What? I would never. Ever."  The delivery man waits. "Soo should I bring this back to the factory?" "Yes, Please." The delivery guy leaves. Mias mom shuts the door. "Oh young lady Your grounded. No phone." "WHAT?! I didnt order anything!" "Yeah right. Go to your room, NOW!"   Mia runs into her room and starts to cry. For hours. She's upset. It's now night. Mias mom is making dinner ğŸ½. "Mia, Dinners ready.." 
"Cominggg...." Mia walks out of her room, Groggy. She sits down and eats. "Soooo, hun, Do you like it?"  "A bit."   "Oh...I thought you liked my cooking..."  "I do, Im a little groggy though." 
Part 3 in a hour or so  
"Why are you groggy? Did you sleep good?" "Yeah, Im just sleepy." "Well thats fine. Eat up so you can get energy for school tomorrow." OK, mom."  Mia eats her dinner. (Chicken nuggets and sauce) And goes back to sleep. The next day, Her mom calls her for breakfast. "Sweetie, Breakfasts ready!!" Mia didnt answer. Mom was worried. "Sweetie?" Mias mom walked in her room. To see her with dark red eyes and long nails. "Sweetie, Its not Halloween." Mias mom stared at her for a moment, Before speaking again. "Sweetie, Breakfast is done. Ok so once, this was when my grandmother was visiting and staying at our house. And in our kitchen, we have 3 windows and a back door. There was this one window where u can look outside of. And basically, my grandmother was looking out there. After a minute or so, she went to my dad asking if that was him outside (btw this was in the morning) 
but the thing is, he was never outside in the first place. She explained that she saw something pass by fast and was gonna go around into the backyard. She was gonna go to the back door to see if it would come, but she said turned back and went back fast again. We were all confused cuz none of us saw it except for her. So, my dad decided to check the cameras. (We have cameras outside that ALWAYS detect if someone passes by. Even animals, even us) and when he checked the footage, no one was there, so we went outside to test it and go infront of the camera, and it detected us, but not the figure that our grandmother saw. She said it looked like they had on a white shirt and black or red pants, and my father had on  similar clothes (black top, red shorts). So to this day, i think my grandnother saw a spirit or ghost because she said it isnt her first time seeing one, she saw one when she was a child.

As the days passed, Emily's transformation became more pronounced. She would wander the streets, her eyes vacant, her smile twisted. People avoided her, fearing the strange influence that had taken hold of her.

The townsfolk tried to figure out what had happened to Emily, but she wouldn't respond. It was as if she was trapped in a world of her own, a world controlled by the stranger's dark powers.

One by one, more people began to fall under the stranger's spell. They would gather in the town square, their eyes black, their movements robotic. The townsfolk realized that the stranger had left behind a dark legacy, a curse that spread like a disease.

A small group of survivors banded together, determined to uncover the truth behind the stranger's powers. They scoured the abandoned house, searching for clues. In the attic, they found a journal belonging to the stranger.

The journal revealed a dark history. The stranger had been collecting souls for centuries, using them to fuel his own twisted powers. Ravenswood was just the latest stop in his eternal journey.

The survivors realized that they had to destroy the source of the stranger's power. They searched the house from top to bottom, finally finding a hidden chamber deep beneath the earth. Inside, they found a small, ornate box.

As they opened the box, a dark energy burst forth, threatening to consume them. But they stood firm, determined to break the curse. With a collective effort, they destroyed the box, shattering the stranger's hold on the town.

Slowly, the townsfolk began to return to normal. Emily's eyes cleared, and she remembered fragments of her past. The town of Ravenswood began to heal, but the memory of the stranger's dark powers lingered, a cautionary tale about the horrors that lurked in the shadows.

But as the townsfolk looked up at the night sky, they noticed something strange. A figure, tall and gaunt, stood on the hill, watching them. The stranger had blood, your still here?!

Thomas Grey was the kind of kid who didnâ€™t lie â€” except about one thing: the basement.

One Friday, his mom got called into a night shift at the hospital. â€œDonâ€™t go poking around,â€ she warned. â€œDinnerâ€™s in the fridge. Iâ€™ll be back by morning.â€

As soon as she pulled out of the driveway, Thomas stood in front of the basement door. He stared at it. The metal handle shimmered under the hallway light.

This time, it was unlocked.

His heart thudded in his chest.

He opened the door.

The smell hit him first â€” sour, damp, like rotten leaves and meat. The steps descended into darkness. He flicked on the light switch. A single bulb flickered weakly at the bottom.

He crept down.

The basement wasâ€¦ empty. Just gray walls, old cobwebs, and a workbench with dusty tools. For a moment, he felt stupid.

But then he heard it.
A whisper.

â€œThoooomassssâ€¦â€

He froze.

The whisper came from the wall. Or rather, behind it. A section of brick near the back looked newer, like it had been sealed recently. He stepped closer.

The whisper turned to a moan. â€œPleaseâ€¦ helpâ€¦â€

Thomasâ€™s fingers shook as he grabbed a rusted hammer from the workbench. He chipped at the bricks. Bit by bit, the wall gave way.

And then he saw it â€” an eye.

A real human eye, wide and bloodshot, peering out at him from behind a small gap in the bricks.

Thomas screamed and stumbled back. The voice cried louder now. â€œPlease! Please! Let me out! Iâ€™m still alive!â€

He ran. Up the stairs. Slammed the basement door shut and locked it. His heart felt like it would rip through his ribs.

When his mother got home at 4 a.m., she found him curled up in the hallway, pale and shaking.

He pointed to the door. â€œThereâ€™s someone down there! Behind the wall!â€

Her face didnâ€™t change. Not even a flicker.

â€œThomas,â€ she said calmly. â€œThatâ€™s not your concern.â€

She reached into her bag and pulled out a keyring â€” with one silver key Thomas had never seen before.

He watched in stunned silence as she unlocked the door and walked down the steps without hesitation.

The light flicked off behind her.

A minute passed. Then two. Thenâ€”

Thud.

Drag.

Whisper.

The door locked from the other side.

Thomas never saw his mother again.

And the screams didnâ€™t stop. They just got louder.

ğŸ•¯ï¸ The Watcher of Westfield

In 2014, a family bought their dream home in Westfield, New Jersey: a beautiful six-bedroom house in a quiet, upscale neighborhood. But within days of moving in, strange letters began appearing in their mailboxâ€”typed, anonymous, and terrifying.

> â€œDo you know what lies within the walls of 657 Boulevard? Iâ€™ve been watching it for decades...â€

Each letter became more sinister. The writer claimed to be "The Watcher," someone chosen to watch the house and its inhabitants. They knew the familyâ€™s names, the children's nicknames, and even referenced renovations the owners were planningâ€”as if they were being watched from inside.

> â€œIt cries to me to come and claim itâ€¦ Iâ€™m waiting for you.â€

The family stopped sleeping. They installed cameras, alarms, and began to fear every creak of the floor. The letters continued. In one, the Watcher asked:

> â€œWill the young blood play in the basement? Who has the rooms facing the street? Iâ€™ll know as soon as you move inâ€¦â€

They never moved in. Months later, they sold the house at a loss. And still, no one has ever discovered who the Watcher was. Some think it was a disturbed neighbor. Others believe it was someone obsessed with the house itself.

To this day, 657 Boulevard remains infamous.

The old house stood on a hill overlooking the town, its darkened windows like vacant eyes staring out at nothing. Everyone in Oakhaven knew about the Blackwood place, and everyone knew to stay away. Stories whispered through generations spoke of Silas Blackwood, a recluse who, it was said, dabbled in things best left undisturbed. He'd vanished fifty years ago, leaving the house and its secrets to rot.
One sweltering July night, as a storm brewed on the horizon, a group of teenagers â€” fueled by bravado and cheap thrills â€” dared each other to spend an hour inside. Liam, always the ringleader, pushed open the creaking front door, a sound like a tortured moan. Dust motes danced in the last slivers of twilight filtering through the grime-caked windows. The air was heavy, stagnant, carrying the faint, metallic tang of something ancient and unidentifiable.
They explored, flashlights cutting shaky paths through the gloom. A grand staircase, its banister carved with grotesque faces, led to the upper floor. Downstairs, the living room held skeletal furniture draped in white sheets, like ghosts awaiting a sÃ©ance. It was in the study, however, that the true unease began. Bookshelves lined with leather-bound volumes, some titled in languages none of them recognized, filled the walls. On a cluttered desk, among dried inkwells and yellowed parchment, lay a single, open journal.
Sarah, the most academically inclined of the group, picked it up. Her eyes widened as she read the spidery script. "It's Silas Blackwood's," she whispered, her voice barely audible

So my cousin came at my grandparent's house to visit them and I knew she would come so I was here too! We usually bring toys to play so yea now it was my turn to bring some. We hugged eachother and we immediately went upstairs to play. We started a roleplay and my cousin had to go to the toilet. I waited for her to come and then when she came she said she heard some weird noises so I agreed because I also heard them. We felt a little weird because we were single upstairs because the people were downstairs so my cousin was braver than me and she said "let's check!" So we went where we heard it. I stopped my cousin and I said "but there is our great grandmother's room and she passed away" so what it could be? She entered the room so I also did behind her. She looked with attention but then I freaked out and also her because we started to hear scratching noises from the window. I pointed with my jaw a little open to the window and there was a black figure so my cousin ran and she left me behind but I also ran after her. We went downstairs and we talked about the black figure from the window. Then we got brave and we went to check!

[Part 2 at 0 likes! ğŸ’—]

We went upstairs again and we went to our great grandmother's room to check again. Now the black figure wasn't there anymore but it was in the other room because we heard the weird noises again. We checked and there it was a weird creature but it wasn't the first one. At night we had a sleepover and we decided to sleep upstairs because we wanted to play again plus we didn't care about the creature thinking it was just our imagination. We were playing but we got tired so we went downstairs to get some night snacks. We got some chips, fruits and drinks and we went into the bed to watch television. We were comfortable when suddenly a light appeared behind the curtains so we went on the balcony to check. There was our grandpa with a lantern checking something that he heard. We said "grandpa, what are u looking for?" and his response was "I heard some weird noises.."

[Part 3 later! â¤]


Ok so my grandpa went into the garden with the lantern but we came too. Then we saw a humanoid figure but it dissapeared immediately. We went into the home fast as we could and we told the people (mum,dad, grandma,uncle and aunt) what we saw and they believed us so the next day me and my cousin checked the garden and there was no one. It was night, we decided to have another sleepover so we'd let the curtains open and we watched our favourite film with our favourite snacks. The sleepover was about to check if the black figure would appear. It was 2 am and we were tired. My cousin feel asleep after a few minutes but there was a shadow reflecting in our room because outside was pitch black and the black figure was outside so I freaked out and woke up my cousin pointing at the shadow. She took a photo of it and then went to check (she is older so she is braver) and the figure dissapeared. The a theory came in my mind and I told my cousin "hey, if the first place where the figure came was the great grandmother's place, let's check it!" So we took a lamp and went into the room. I was shaking and shivering because even if it was my idea, I am scared. We checked and there was no one..
