: So one day I went to Mongolia with a couple of friends when I was 9, and I was the oldest in the group. One night my friend and I woke up to a man screaming his head off, right outside or second story window. Iâ€™m talking-voice-is- getting-hoarse-because-you-think-youâ€™re-gonna-die-screaming. It went on for hours, and we had no idea what to do. Eventually I get up close to the window, and when I looked outside, terrified this dude is gonna see me, thereâ€™s on one there. I shut the window and the screaming stopped immediately. 


      Our friend who was in the room, connected ours didnâ€™t hear a thing, and neither did the other group of friends in a different room on the same floor. The only ones who heard it was me and my friend who I was sharing a room with.


 Creepy, but nothing bad happened to us, and now itâ€™s all over right?

WRONG!


So that night Iâ€™m like, I am NOT getting woke up again, I donâ€™t care what loud noises people decide to make. I put my earplugs in, I got my eye mask on, life is good and I sleep throughout the night. The next morning, my friend in the other room connected to ours comes into my room and says, â€œThe police was here last night.â€ 

Someone knocked on our door, and I ignored it, but they knocked again, so I answered and it was the â€œpoliceâ€. They walked into our room and looked everywhere and left. 

Because I was wearing earplugs, I slept throughout the whole thing. What makes this terrifying for me, is that we were in a foreign country-we have no idea what the police uniforms look like, or what there allowed to do. Again we escaped unscathed, but sometimes I shudder to think, what might have happenedâ€¦if it had been someone pretending to be a police. 

Turns out that police was a serial killer and was looking for weapons if they tried to find any and REAL police have been trying to look for him for a long, long time.

The Ghost Flight
It was a dark, stormy night when Flight 713 took off from the airport. Passengers settled in, unaware that this flight would be anything but normal. As the plane soared through thick clouds, the cockpit suddenly went silent. The pilots disappeared without a trace, leaving only eerie silence.
Strange things started happening. The lights flickered and dimmed, and passengers began to hear whispers coming from the overhead compartments. One by one, they saw shadowy figures lurking in the corners of the cabinâ€”ghostly faces with hollow eyes staring at them.
Then, the hijackers appearedâ€”men in dark masks, but their faces were distorted, twisted with anger and sadness. They didnâ€™t speak, only gestured wildly, as if warning the passengers about a terrible secret. One of the passengers, a young woman named Emily, saw the ghostly figures behind the hijackersâ€”victims from long ago, trying to warn her.
Suddenly, the plane dropped sharply. The ghostly faces grew closer, reaching out with cold, invisible hands. Emily realized the plane was being haunted by spiritsâ€”victims of a past tragedyâ€”who had taken control of the flight to seek justice.
In the chaos, Emily remembered an old story: to escape the ghosts, she had to face her fears and tell their story. With trembling voice, she spoke aloud about the tragedy that haunted the spirits. The shadows wavered and slowly vanished, the hijackers disappeared, and the plane stabilized.
When they finally landed, no one remembered what had happenedâ€”only Emily knew the truth about the ghostly flight, and the restless spirits that still lingered in the skies.

Title: The Sixfold Whisper

Each summer, the six of them gathered in the sleepy town of Greywood, where an abandoned watermill by the misty river was their secret hideaway. Layla, Alice, Olivia, Ellie, Poppy, and Tillie loved one thing: whispering secrets into the river at midnight, passing folded paper with their deepest fears. Legend said: if you whisper them six times, the river remembersâ€”and answers back.

This year, curious whispers began echoing through the watermillâ€”as if the old wooden walls absorbed and returned their words.

Night One â€“ Answers in Ripples
Ellie was first. She whispered six times: â€œI donâ€™t belong.â€ That night, she awoke to the sound of six soft knocks at her doorâ€”each one reverberating with a voice she recognized: her own. She didnâ€™t open it. In the morning, she found six tiny puddles of river water on her floor.

Night Two â€“ Echoes Grow
Poppy confessed her deepest fear: â€œIâ€™m not strong enough.â€ That stormy night, she dreamt of six drowning girls, calling for help. She woke gasping, drenchedâ€”but it hadnâ€™t rained. In her hand, she found a folded note: â€œIs six enough?â€ No signature.

Night Three â€“ Sixfold Pact
They met at the mill in daylight, shaken. Layla suggested performing the full sixfold whisper ritual: six fears, six whispers, one answer. They wrote:

Layla: â€œIâ€™m alone in my pain.â€
Alice: â€œI wonâ€™t forgive myself.â€
Olivia: â€œI am just a shadow.â€
Ellie: â€œI donâ€™t belong.â€
Poppy: â€œIâ€™m not strong enough.â€
Tillie: â€œIâ€™m lost.â€
At midnight, they whispered their words one after the otherâ€”six times eachâ€”into the riverâ€™s dark surface.

Night Four â€“ The Response
They waited. In the old mill, the wheel began to turn on its own. Olivia gasped: six ripples crossed the water inside the millrace, concentric and alive. From the darkness stir whispering voices:

â€œYou are one.â€
â€œYou are two.â€
â€œâ€¦six.â€
And then silence.

Night Five â€“ Unraveling
In the following days, each girl began changing.

Alice woke with her reflection empty-eyedâ€”until she didn't remember the whisper.
Olivia found shadowy figures trailing her always in photographsâ€”always six.
Poppy discovered in her dreams six versions of herself, drowningâ€”but never dying.
Tillie heard six voices calling her name when she looked in mirrors.
Layla woke to find six written apologies scrawled in her notebookâ€”none by her.
And Ellie? She was gone that night. No note. No traceâ€”just that single candle left burning by the riverside.

Night Six â€“ Final Whisper
Desperate, the five remaining girls returned to the mill. The river had swallowed the night sky. They whispered again: six voices uttering one nameâ€”Ellieâ€”hoping to bring her back.

The waterwheel stopped. The river stilled. The water in the mill rose until it pooled around their ankles. And then, soft footsteps from six directions, calling:

â€œSixâ€¦isâ€¦nowâ€¦one.â€
Their lights went out. Cold water closed overhead.

Morning â€” Six Become None
The next dawn, the mill was empty. No footprints. No scream. No ripples.

In the mud by the riverbank lay six folded notes:

â€œI belong.â€
â€œI forgive.â€
â€œI am.â€
â€œI belong.â€
â€œI am strong.â€
â€œI am found.â€
They whispered, the river answered.

And now: itâ€™s silent.

Title: Six Shadows in Glass

Six friendsâ€”Izzy, Sophie, Florence, Lauren, Thalia, and Sofiaâ€”decided to spend a weekend in an old lakeside manor. Inside, a massive antique mirror stood in the grand hallway, the kind that seemed to absorb light and breathe shadows.

Night One â€“ Whispers in the Mirror
They circled it, teasing each other:

Sophie challenged, â€œMirror, mirrorâ€¦ show us six today.â€
Izzy whispered her full nameâ€”and the glass briefly fogged, though the room was cold and still.
But Florence noticed something odd. When she looked, there were seven reflectionsâ€”six girls and one extra figure, just at the edge, faceless.

Night Two â€“ Reflections Grow Darker
That evening, Lauren dared them to perform a game: each girl would stare into the mirror, say her full name, and ask aloud, "Who watches me?" They did.

One by one:

Thalia saw her reflection blink when she didn't, lips curling into a sinister grin.
Izzy gasped when her mirror-version raised a hand to her throat, but Izzy herself touched her own throatâ€”pulselessly calm.
Sophie saw six flickering images around her own, whispering names none of the friends recognized.
Then the mirror went black, reflections vanishing altogether.

Night Three â€“ Shadows Cross Over
Sofia, the courageous one, crept to the mirror late at night. She pressed her palm to the glass.

Her reflection smiled back in a way that felt alive.

Sophie found her the next morningâ€”collapsed before the mirror, eyes wide open, skin chalky. The others rushed to her, but Sofia was gone.

Where the mirror had stood, now there were six empty spaces in its frame.

Night Four â€“ The Last Five
Panic settled like ice. They dared not speak their names again.

But the mirror reappeared that night on the hallway wall, clearer than before. One by one, more girls vanished:

Florence disappeared from a photograph taken that eveningâ€”her face blurred to pale mist.
Izzy vanished when Lauren looked just away for a moment.
Sophie was dragged into the mirrorâ€™s surface, her voice echoing: â€œSay my name.â€
Thalia and Lauren remainedâ€”terrified, guilt-stricken.

Final Night â€“ Two Left
Only Thalia and Lauren stayed, waging silent war with the mirror. They covered it with sheets, but the glass sighed behind them, a low rattle like skeletal laughter.

Thalia whispered, â€œWe made them say their namesâ€¦ we invited it in.â€

Lauren pressed her ear to the sheet: six voices, faint and broken.

One by one, Lauren heard them call her name. She froze, sobbing.

When she looked, Thalia had turned to face the mirror, eyes vacant.

Thalia's lips moved.

Lauren screamed a full name.

The sheet dropped.

Morning
Lauren woke alone. The mirror stood empty, the room stale and silent.

Six reflections had crossed over.

All the girls were goneâ€”pulled into the glass, erased from this world.

Lauren touched the mirrorâ€™s cold surface. She staredâ€”and for a fraction of a second, she saw her own missing eyes, staring back, far beyond her.

Title: Echoes in the Fog

Izabel, Sophie, Florence, Lauren, Thalia, and Sofia had been inseparable since birthâ€”their birthdays always falling within a week of each other. When they turned sixteen, they celebrated with a trip to secluded Mistwood Lake, hidden deep in a forest perpetually shrouded in chill fog.

On the first night, they gathered around a bonfire and made a blood pact: â€œBy this pact, we swear we will always be six. Not one less.â€ Their laughter echoed into the mistâ€¦ and something answered.

By dawn, Thalia was missing. The girls searched frantically, finding her pendant lying at the waterâ€™s edgeâ€”but no sign of her. Digging through memories, they realized nobody could quite recall when Thalia had vanished. In one moment she was there, the next she... wasnâ€™t.

That day brought nightmares:

Izabel awoke to whispers swapping her name for "Thalia," each time she spoke.
Sophie stared at her reflection and saw a girl sheâ€™d never met wearing Thaliaâ€™s pendant.
Florence, the peacekeeper, found ancient words scratched into the cabins: "Still six, always six."
Lauren heard six voices calling her nameâ€”but only five faces were present.
Sofia found her phone filled with selfiesâ€”with a shadowy sixth figure silently standing beside them, half-blurred and wrong.
As the days passed, they drifted apart in terror. Bonds snapped, memories frayed. Only one thing remained constant: the lake. On the third night, they returned to its edge. The mist thickened, swirling like living smoke, and a distorted silhouette emerged from the water.

It looked like Thaliaâ€”except its eyes were empty voids, face warped, the pactâ€™s blood smeared across her throat. It raised a hand and whispered, â€œYou broke the pact.â€

Panic erupted. Each girl felt a cold claw around her heart, pullingâ€”erasing.

Sophie screamed, "We always swore sixâ€”"

The creature smirked. â€œBut nowâ€¦ you're only five.â€

In that moment, Izabel lunged into the mist, grabbing Sophieâ€™s hand. A wave of frigid air slammed them both. They tumbled backward as the creature dragged into the lakeâ€”taking Sofiaâ€™s hand last. Her scream cut short, swallowed by the fog.

Morning came with the fog liftedâ€”but only four girls remained, huddled on the shore. They found a single, damp pact written in blood on a driftwood plank: â€œSix must remain.â€

But nobody remembered who left.
They only knew one terrible truth: the lake keeps its promise.

ğŸ•¯ï¸ "The Voice Behind the Wall" ğŸ•¯ï¸

When Leah moved into the old Victorian house on the outskirts of town, she knew it came with a history. The real estate agent called it â€œcharacter.â€ The neighbors called it cursed.

The first night was quietâ€”until 3:33 a.m. Thatâ€™s when she heard it.

A voice.

Soft, almost a whisper, coming from behind the wall in her bedroom. It wasnâ€™t muffled like someone next door. It was clearer. Closer.

"Leahâ€¦ are you awake?"

She froze. No one knew she was here yet. No one had called her name.

She pressed her ear against the cold plaster. Silence.

Shrugging it off as her imagination and exhaustion, she went back to sleep.

The second night, it returned. Same time.

This time, it didnâ€™t whisper her name. It laughed.

A dry, cracked, inhuman laughâ€”too loud to be from behind the wall. It felt like it was right next to her, inside the wallâ€¦ or inside her head.

She tore the drywall open the next morning. Nothing. No wiring, no pipes, just dust and a smellâ€”musty, like old blood.

The third night, she set up her phone to record. She fell asleep with every light on.

When she checked the video in the morning, it was five hours of nothingâ€”until 3:33 a.m.

The screen went black, but the audio kept playing.

Footsteps. A dragging sound. Thenâ€¦ the voice.

"Why did you open the wall?"

A long pause. Then a raspy breath.

"Now I can come through."

The last thing on the recording was a sudden, ear-splitting screamâ€”and then the camera was knocked over, the lens shattering.

Leah never watched the footage again.

Because when she looked up from the video, her wallâ€”completely repaired the day beforeâ€”had cracks forming in it again.

And that nightâ€¦

The voice didnâ€™t wait until 3:33.

It spoke to her from right behind her mirror.
A guy walking towards me with a job application.

Title: â€œRoom 313â€

Part I: The Guest Who Checked Out
The Bellmore Hotel was nearly forgottenâ€”one of those roadside motels tucked off an old highway, where the neon buzzes but never fully lights, and the carpets always smell like mold and secrets.

Jason was the night clerk. It wasnâ€™t a glamorous job, but it was quiet. Until the man in black checked into Room 313.

He didnâ€™t give a name. Paid in cash. No luggage. No ID.

Jason handed him the key and muttered, â€œYouâ€™re the only one on that floor.â€

The man just smiled.

A week later, when housekeeping finally went to checkâ€¦ Room 313 was empty.

Not â€œhe checked outâ€ empty. The bed was still made. The TV was on. The lights were off. The walls were covered in writing, scratched into the wallpaper like claw marks:

â€œI never left. I never left. I never left.â€
And on the bathroom mirror, written in something thick and brown-red:

â€œDonâ€™t let them put anyone else in here.â€
Jason requested a transfer.

They denied it.

Part II: The Door That Opened Itself
Jason started hearing things.

Footsteps above, when no one was booked on the third floor.

Whispers in the hallway: fragmented, like voices underwater. One night, during his shift, the front desk phone rang. The ID said: Room 313.

Jason stared at the screen for a long time before picking it up.

All he heard was breathing. Ragged. Wet.

Then a voice that sounded like his own said:
â€œYouâ€™re not supposed to hear this.â€

He unplugged the phone.

But the next night, it rang again.

Part III: The Camera Footage
He asked the manager to pull the security footageâ€”just to prove he wasnâ€™t crazy.

They watched the tape from 2:00 AM to 3:00 AM.

Nothing unusual at first.

Then they saw it.

Room 313â€™s door slowly opened. A dark figure stepped out, crawlingâ€”not walking, but slithering on all fours like an insect. The lights flickered as it moved. Its head twitched at impossible angles. No face. Just a void where a face should be.

The figure crawled down the hallway and stopped.

Right in front of the security camera.

It stared directly into the lens for 43 minutes without blinking.

Then the tape ended. Just static.

The manager laughed nervously, shut the laptop, and said, â€œMust be a glitch.â€

Jason handed in his resignation the next morning.

Part IV: But You Can Never Leave
Jason moved three states away. Got a job at a gas station. Tried to forget.

But some nights, the lights flicker there too.

And last night, Room 313 called his cellphone.

He doesnâ€™t know how that number exists.

He didnâ€™t answer.

But the voicemail is still there. Just breathing.
And at the very end, his own voice whispering:

â€œWeâ€™re all in the room now. And you left the door open.â€
THE END

Part I: The Picture Frame
Nine-year-old Lily hadnâ€™t spoken since her mother died.

Sheâ€™d been in the car when the crash happenedâ€”glass and blood, the sound of her motherâ€™s final breath like paper tearingâ€”and now she just stared. Her father, Mark, tried everything: therapists, schools, toys. Nothing reached her.

Until the day he brought out the old mirror.

It had been her motherâ€™s favorite. Antique, with a bronze frame carved into thorny roses. Mark put it in Lilyâ€™s room, hoping some memory would spark comfort.

That night, Lily whispered her first word in months.

â€œMommy.â€

Part II: Mirror Talk
Mark thought he was dreaming when he heard Lily giggling.

He stood outside her room, just past midnight. Inside, she was sitting cross-legged on the floor, facing the mirror, speaking in soft tones.

â€œI missed you, Mommy.â€

His stomach dropped.

He stepped in, but Lily turned and shook her head violently. â€œYouâ€™ll scare her,â€ she hissed. Her eyes were wet with joy.

Mark looked into the mirror.

Nothing. Just a reflection. But Lily saw something else. Something behind the glass. Her smile was wide, innocent.

â€œMommy says she can come back if I keep talking to her. Every night. No matter what.â€

That night, Mark moved the mirror into the attic.

That night, he heard scratching on the ceiling.

Part III: Mommyâ€™s Face
Lily wouldnâ€™t eat. Wouldnâ€™t sleep unless the mirror was nearby. Mark gave inâ€”put it back in her room.

Thatâ€™s when the drawings started.

They were always the same: a woman with black eyes and a mouth stitched shut, reaching out from a broken mirror. Lily called it "Mommyâ€™s Other Face."

â€œShe had to change when she went to the place under,â€ Lily explained. â€œThe cold place. She said the pain made her look different now. But she still loves me.â€

Mark cried in the kitchen that night, holding his wifeâ€™s old photograph.

The next morning, the photo was gone. In its place was a new one. Of her, yesâ€”but distorted. Her eyes blackened. Her smile too wide. And in the photo frame, etched like it had been scratched in:

"Iâ€™m coming back. You promised."
Part IV: The Price of Return
Lilyâ€™s skin grew paler by the day.

She said Mommy was â€œborrowing her strength.â€ That it was okay. â€œSheâ€™s just using me to open the mirror all the way.â€

Mark found a note one morning. A childâ€™s handwriting:

"Tonight is the last step. Please donâ€™t stop it. I want her back. Even if sheâ€™s not the same."
He burst into Lilyâ€™s room that night.

The mirror was no longer reflecting the roomâ€”it was a window. On the other side was a dark hallway, and from it came the sound of wet footsteps.

Lily stood at the center of a circle drawn in red.

â€œDonâ€™t ruin it!â€ she screamed, voice not entirely hers.

The mirror cracked. From the broken glass, hands emergedâ€”long, gray, and trembling.

Mark grabbed Lily, but she looked up at him with empty eyes.

â€œShe promised sheâ€™d bring Mommy back. She never said sheâ€™d leave me behind.â€

And then she vanished.

Part V: The Grief That Remains
The police never found Lily.

They found the mirror, shattered. Blood on the edges. No footprints. No signs of break-in. Mark told them she ran away.

But in his heart, he knew.

He sleeps in the living room now. Drinks too much. Talks to no one.

And every so often, he hears a childâ€™s voice from the attic.

â€œSheâ€™s almost ready to come through.â€

Sometimes, when he looks in the mirror, he swears he sees Lilyâ€™s faceâ€”her mouth stitched shut, eyes wide with terrorâ€”begging him to help.

But he canâ€™t.

Because sometimes, she speaks with her motherâ€™s voice.

THE END

Part I: The House in Black Hollow
James Everly had no business inheriting anything from his estranged uncle. They hadn't spoken in 15 yearsâ€”not since James fled Black Hollow after that night with the well. So when the letter arrived from a law office, telling him he was the sole heir of the Everly Estate, he thought it was a scam.

But the keys were real. The property deed was real. And the nightmares that returned the moment he stepped onto the creaking porchâ€¦ those were the most real of all.

The house hadn't changed. The gabled roof still clawed at the sky like a broken spine, and the windows blinked with the grime of years. Inside, the air was wet and thick, as if the walls were breathing. James felt it immediatelyâ€”the presence. Not just memory. Not just dread. Something was in that house. Waiting.

Part II: The Hole in the Floor
Three nights after moving in, James was woken by scratching. Not mice. Not rats. Something larger.

It came from beneath the floorboards of the old parlorâ€”the room his uncle had always kept locked. James pried the boards open, heart hammering, and foundâ€¦ a hole. Perfectly circular. The wood had been gnawed, bitten, into the shape of a mouth.

And from that hole, a pale hand reached out.

James didn't scream. He couldnâ€™t. The hand froze, sensing the air. Then it retreated slowly, scraping the sides with its nails. James closed the boards and nailed them shut, sealing whatever it was inside.

But the scratching came back. Louder. Angrier. Closer.

Part III: The Pale Man
James tried to leave. His car wouldn't start. His phone was dead. Every window he smashed healed overnight. The house wouldn't let him go.

So he waited. Waited for the thing to show itself.

And on the seventh night, it did.

He woke to find the boards torn apart, wood splinters scattered like bones. The hole yawned wide, black and slick with some kind of ichor. From it emerged a manâ€”or what was left of one.

Its skin was paper-white and translucent, stretched over bones too long and too sharp. Its face had no lips, just a permanent, torn smile, exposing hundreds of tiny, yellow teeth. Its eyes were lidless, sunken pits that wept black fluid.

The Pale Man crawled forward, sniffing the air. James was frozen. The thing turned to him, its head cocking like a dog, and it whispered in a voice like crumbling paper:

â€œYou left me in the dark. You let me starve.â€
James screamed and ran. But the house had changed. The hallways stretched, rooms looped into themselves. He ran for hours, doors leading to dead ends and mirrors and worseâ€”reflections of himself being consumed by the thing.

Part IV: The Truth Beneath
In his desperation, James returned to the hole. He dove into the blackness, falling for what felt like hours. At the bottom was not soil or rockâ€”but a chamber, ancient and pulsing with veins of red light.

He saw carvings. Symbols. Worship. The Pale Man was not a ghost. He was summoned. Fed. Imprisoned.

And years ago, when James was a child, he helped his uncle seal the Pale Man in the floor. They used the blood of the family dog. James remembered the screaming. He remembered the bargain: â€œThe house protects us as long as we feed it.â€

But then James ran away.

The house hadnâ€™t forgotten.

Part V: The New Host
James never escaped.

They say sometimes, at night, you can hear screams from the Everly house. Sometimes, the parlor door swings open on its own. And if you're quietâ€¦ youâ€™ll hear scratching beneath the floorboards.

They say a new Pale Man lives there now.

And heâ€™s very, very hungry.

THE END

They found her three months after she disappeared.

Emma Calloway, 17, abducted from a gas station parking lot on a rainy Tuesday night, was discovered in the storage basement of an abandoned roadside motel, bound but alive. Malnourished. Bruised. But alive.

She was taken to the hospital, sedated, then questioned. Her answers didnâ€™t make sense.

â€œHe never touched me. He just watched.â€
The man who kidnapped her was never found. No DNA, no fingerprints, no signs of forced entry into the motel. Yet Emma swore he came every night and stood in the corner of the room.

â€œHe never spoke. But I heard him anyway.â€
They assumed trauma. Hallucinations. Delirium.

Then the police reviewed the motelâ€™s hidden camera footage from before the place shut down. Room 209â€”the one sheâ€™d been found inâ€”had been locked and vacant for over a year before her disappearance. No bookings. No maintenance. Nothing.

But in the static-ridden security footage from the hallway camera, there were gaps. Blanks. Entire nights just... erased. Glitches.

The strange part? Whenever the footage did play, the door to Room 209 could be seen opening. Not all the way. Just enough for someoneâ€”or somethingâ€”to look out.

When the police asked Emma about it, her vitals spiked. She whispered:

â€œIt wasnâ€™t a man.â€
She wouldnâ€™t say more.

They released her. Gave her therapy. Medication. Tried to help her adjust.

Two weeks later, she was found in her room at home.

Sheâ€™d sealed the windows, barricaded the door, covered every mirror, every screen. Scrawled â€œDONâ€™T LOOK AT HIMâ€ over and over across the walls in red marker.

There was no forced entry.

No sign of a break-in.

Just her bodyâ€”lifeless, paleâ€”and the phone lying next to her.

The screen showed a blurry photo, taken in the dark.

In the corner of the room...
A tall, emaciated figure with no eyes and a cracked, gaping smile.

Facing the camera.

Watching.

â€œThe Birthday in the Basementâ€

It was supposed to be a surprise party.

I turned 14 that year, and my cousin Jade told me she had something â€œepicâ€ planned. She blindfolded me in the car, told me to trust her, and we drove for what felt like hoursâ€”even though her house was only ten minutes away.

When the car stopped, she helped me out and whispered, â€œDonâ€™t take off the blindfold yet.â€ Her hand was cold. Too cold.

We walked down what felt like stepsâ€”echoing ones. Concrete. My gut twisted.

When the blindfold came off, we were in her basement.

Sort of.

There were streamers and balloons, but they wereâ€¦ wrong. Torn. Burned around the edges. The balloons werenâ€™t floating; they sagged, covered in black, dripping slime. A cake sat in the middle of the roomâ€”gray, cracked, with thirteen black candles instead of fourteen.

â€œJade?â€ I said.

She just stared at me. Her head tilted too far, her smile stretched too wide. And then, the lights went out.

Pitch black.

The silence was heavy. Then came a sound Iâ€™ll never forget: whispering. Hundreds of voices, layered and echoing, like they were crawling under my skin. I turned to run, but something grabbed my ankle. Cold, wet fingers. I kicked and screamed, crawling up the stairs, but the steps never endedâ€”they just kept going, like I was climbing forever.

And then I was back in the basement.

Same spot.

Same cake.

Except this time, there were only twelve candles.

I screamed for help. No one came. Jade was gone. In her place stood a girl with no eyes, her mouth stitched shut. She pointed to the cake.

A voice hissed behind me: â€œMake a wish.â€

I ran.

Somehow, I made it out. Stumbled into the daylight. My parents were there, confused, saying theyâ€™d been looking for me for hoursâ€”but we were still in Jadeâ€™s driveway. I told them what happened. They just stared at me.

â€œThereâ€™s no basement in Jadeâ€™s house,â€ they said.

And when I looked in the mirror that night, there was a streak of soot across my cheekâ€”and a faint black candle mark burned into the back of my hand.

I never found out what really happened.
I never celebrated my birthday again.
And sometimes, at 3:14 a.m., I still hear it:
â€œMake a wish.â€

Part 2: Thirteen Candles

After that day, I stopped talking about what happened. My parents thought I was just shaken upâ€”maybe hallucinating, maybe too much sugar and sleep deprivation. I let them believe that.

But I couldnâ€™t stop seeing it.

The mark on my handâ€”that faint burn shaped like a candleâ€”it never went away. Some nights, it glows, faint and red, especially when the clock strikes 3:14 a.m. The exact time I escaped the basement.

Or thought I did.

Three nights after the party, I started dreaming of the girl againâ€”the eyeless one with the stitched mouth. In the dream, she walks toward me slowly, her head twitching at unnatural angles, her hand outstretched. Every time, she gets a little closer. Every time, I wake up screaming, sweat freezing cold, as if Iâ€™ve just climbed out of ice water.

And then, Jade disappeared.

Her parents filed a missing person report. Last seen at the library, but never came home. No one could find her phone. No notes. No clues.

I didnâ€™t tell them what I knew. Who would believe me? That she took me to a basement that doesnâ€™t exist? That she changedâ€”became something else?

The next night, I made a mistake.

I stayed up until 3:14 a.m.

And when the clock struck, every candle in the house lit itself. I donâ€™t even own that many candles. But they were there, flickering silently, their flames black and motionless.

In the hallway mirror, my reflection was smiling.

I wasnâ€™t.

Then the girl appeared againâ€”this time, not in a dream.

She was standing at the end of the hall, head tilted, stitched mouth trembling. And behind herâ€¦ stood others. Blurred faces. Burned party hats. Shadowed children, all frozen in mid-scream.

I stepped back.

The girl pointed at me again. But this time, I understood.

There were twelve candles left.

One for each year. One for each victim. And nowâ€¦ she wanted mine.

So, my parents have always told me to NEVER go into the creepy woods in our neighborhood, and I never knew exactly why... 
But one time, my best friend and I, went on a bike ride around noon. It was starting to thunder, so we were about to head inside. But then, my friend thought it would be a good idea to go into the woods that everyone told me NOT to go into. I told her it was a bad idea, but she said we would only go in for a little while. I guess I just kinda agreed, and went along with it. But it started to thunder more and more, as we walked deeper into the woods. I told her we should head back home, and she said, "okay, fine." but, as we turned around to walk back home, we realized we were lost in the sketchy woods..... 
As we just continued to walk back home trying to find our way back, (this is were the scary parts happen....) 
I heard a little giggle that sounded like a little girl... I asked my best friend if she heard anything, and she said she didn't hear anything. Then, I just kept hearing the giggle come closer and closer. I was getting scared, but my friend didn't believe me. As we kept walking, she said she wanted to take a selfie with me and her in the woods to send to her other friend, (I have no idea why) I just said, "ok" and we took the selfie. As she sent it to her friend, her friend replied with, "Ummm.... Girls...?" my friend just replied with a, "yeah..???" my best friends friend, then sent the same selfie we sent to her, with a red circle around a little girl, in a white gown, with black long hair, standing behind us, hiding behind a treeâ€¦. Me and my best friend were so terrified... We called her and asked if she edited that. But as we checked the photo, we knew it wasn't edited....... something was really behind us as we took that photoâ€¦.

As we rushed out of the woods.... (we finally knew the way back home) And made it home safely... I then understood why my parents said to never go into the woods..... 
Ever since that day, I could almost feel like the woods was telling me to NEVER come back.....

The house stood alone on a hill, overlooking a town that felt miles away, even though it was just at the base of the winding road. A thick fog clung to the surrounding woods, muffling the world and making it feel impossibly isolated. Sarah had chosen this house for its quiet, its distance from the noise and demands of the city. But now, the silence felt less like peace and more like a vacuum waiting to be filled.
The first night was unsettling. A faint, repetitive thudding echoed from the walls, a sound she couldn't pinpoint. It wasnâ€™t a rodent or a pipe knocking; it had a strange, deliberate rhythm to it. She tried to rationalize it â€“ the old house settling, perhaps. But the sound persisted, a constant, unsettling pulse in the otherwise silent air.
As days turned into a week, the thudding grew louder, closer. It seemed to be originating from the wall behind her bed. Sleep became a luxury she couldn't afford. The constant thudding, combined with the feeling of being watched, kept her on edge. She'd catch glimpses of movement in her peripheral vision, shadows that lingered too long, and felt a prickling sensation on the back of her neck.
One evening, as she was about to investigate the wall, the thudding stopped abruptly. The sudden silence was even more terrifying than the noise. She stood frozen, listening to her own racing heart, the quiet amplifying every tiny creak of the old house. A whisper, barely audible, brushed against her ear, "I know you're awake". ğŸ˜

Title: The Girl in the Shadows

In the small town of Hollow Creek, stories of the past lingered like fog on a chilly morning. Among them, the tale of the girl in the shadows haunted every corner. Rumors circulated about a girl named Elara, who had lived in an old, decaying house at the edge of the woods. She was said to have been beautiful once, with long, flowing hair and a smile that could light up the darkest days. But that was before the accidentâ€”a night when the moon hid behind storm clouds and darkness swallowed the world whole.

After that fateful night, Elara was never seen the same way again. Whispers spoke of how she had changed, her eyes dimmed as shadows wrapped around her like a shroud. They said she wandered through the trees, her laughter echoing eerily in the wind, only to fade into the eerie silence that followed.

One crisp autumn evening, a group of friends dared each other to visit the old house. Driven by a mix of curiosity and bravado, they grabbed flashlights and set off, unaware that their adventure would turn into something far beyond their imagination.

As they approached the house, it loomed in the fading light, a skeletal structure with windows like darkened eyes. Ivy clung to the walls, and the door hung crookedly on its hinges. The chill in the air nipped at their skin, but they pressed on, their laughter masking the growing unease.

Inside, the floorboards creaked beneath their weight, and dust danced in the beams of their flashlights. Everything felt wrongâ€”like the house itself was watching them. They explored room after room until they found themselves in a dimly lit parlor, where an old mirror hung on the wall, its glass cloudy with age.

As one of the friends approached the mirror, he felt a sudden chill, as if a breath of icy air had swept past him. Staring into the depths of the glass, he gasped. There, reflected behind him, was a glimpse of somethingâ€”no, someone. A girl with long, dark hair, her face partially hidden by shadows, stared back with wide, empty eyes.

â€œDid you see that?â€ he stammered, turning to his friends, but they laughed it off, dismissing it as a trick of the light. They had heard the stories, but their bravado kept them from believing.

Moments later, a soft sound interrupted their laughterâ€”a whisper that floated through the air, murmuring unintelligibly. It grew louder, a haunting melody that seemed to echo around them. Their bravado faltered, hearts racing at the thought of what they might be conjuring. 

â€œWe should go,â€ one girl urged, the unease in her voice palpable. But curiosity, mixed with fear, kept them rooted in place.

Suddenly, the temperature dropped further. Their breath misted in front of them, and a shadow darted across the wall. They turned, eyes wide, straining to see. It was then they found herâ€”Elara. She stood in the corner, a ghostly silhouette, her eyes now glowing with an unnatural light. The whispers formed words, floating like mist in the airâ€” "Help me..."

Panic surged through the group. They turned to flee, but the door slammed shut, trapping them inside. Elara stepped closer, her face now visibleâ€”a haunting beauty twisted by sorrow. â€œYouâ€™ve come to help, havenâ€™t you?â€ she said, her voice echoing as if from a great distance.

Terrified but feeling an odd pull towards her, the bravest among them stepped forward. â€œWhat do you need?â€ he asked, his voice trembling.

â€œFree me from this place,â€ she pleaded, â€œI am bound to the shadows until someone remembers me as I once was.â€ 

Recognizing the tragedy of her story, the friends joined hands, closing their eyes and focusing on the memories of laughter, love, and life. As they opened themselves to the warmth of those feelings, they felt the heaviness in the air begin to lift. The shadows around Elara slithered away, unraveling like threads pulled from a tapestry.

With a final, sincere smile, Elara began to fade, her form washed out by light. â€œThank you,â€ she whispered, her voice fading into a soft breeze that drifted through the room.

The door creaked open, and the friends stumbled into the night, breathless and changed. They looked back at the house, now just a structure bathed in silver moonlight, no longer ominous but peaceful. Hollow Creek would remember Elara, not as a figure of fear, but as a lost girl finally set free.

From that day on, the stories of the girl in the shadows morphed into something newâ€”a tale of hope, connection, and the power of remembrance. Sometimes, in the depths of the woods, you could still hear her laughter, a gentle reminder to cherish the light, even in the darkest times.

So lemme tell you something, this is not fake, Iâ€™ve been in this situationâ€¦

Last night, as I diligently worked on my homework, the soft glow of my Chromebook screen illuminated my quiet room. My fingers danced across the keyboard, eyes fixed on the assignment, fully immersed in the task at hand. It was a typical evening, filled with the familiar rhythm of study.

Suddenly, a subtle flicker caught the very edge of my vision. It was gone almost as quickly as it appeared, a fleeting disturbance in the periphery. I paused, my concentration momentarily broken, and glanced around the room. Nothing. Convinced it was just my imagination, perhaps a trick of the light or an exhausted blink, I returned to my work, trying to recapture my focus. 

But then, it happened again. That same elusive flicker, a brief yet undeniable movement at the corner of my eye. This time, a shiver ran down my spine. It was too distinct to ignore, too precise to be a mere optical illusion. My heart began to beat a little faster, and a prickle of unease settled over me.

The quiet hum of my Chromebook was the only sound echoing in my room last night as I wrestled with a particularly tricky math problem. My textbooks lay scattered around me like fallen soldiers in a losing battle, and the soft glow of the screen cast long shadows that danced with every subtle shift of my posture. I was deep in the labyrinth of quadratic equations, determined to conquer them before the night was through.

It was then, in a moment of intense concentration, that I felt itâ€”a subtle disruption at the very edge of my vision. A flicker, quick and elusive, like a butterfly wing brushing past. I dismissed it, attributing it to fatigue or the play of shadows, and dove back into the numbers, trying to recall the formula for the vertex of a parabola. My brain, however, had already registered the anomaly.

Just as I thought I had a breakthrough with the equation, the flicker returned. This time, it was more defined, a fleeting, almost transparent ripple in the air that seemed to originate from the corner of my room. My breath hitched, and the hairs on my arms rose. It wasn't my imagination; something was there, just beyond the scope of my direct gaze, watching. And it was waiting for me to acknowledge it.

The resort was ordered to close immediately while an investigation into the collapse was conducted.

Scary. The wind howled outside, rattling the windows of the old, abandoned house. Shadows danced on the walls as the branches of the trees scratched against the glass. Every creak and groan of the house sent shivers down my spine. I huddled in the corner, clutching a flashlight to my chest. The storm raged on, the thunder booming so loud it felt like the whole house was shaking. I tried to tell myself it was just a storm, just the wind and rain causing all the noise. But deep down, I knew there was something more sinister at play. Something lurking in the darkness, waiting for the right moment to strike. My heart raced as I listened to the eerie sounds surrounding me, knowing that I was not alone. And then, suddenly, a loud crash echoed through the house, and I knew that whatever was out there had found its way inside. With trembling hands, I turned on the flashlight and pointed it towards the source of the sound. As the beam of light cut through the darkness, my worst fears were realized. Standing before me was a figure cloaked in shadow, its eyes glowing with a malevolent light. I knew then that I was face to face with something truly terrifying.

â€œGet out of there, Jason.â€

I'll tell 1/2 real stories (idk if one is real or not) 





In 1986, a family in a quiet neighborhood began experiencing strange occurrences in their home. At first, it was small thingsâ€”items moving, strange noises at night. But then, one night, they were awakened by a loud bang. Investigating, they found their front door wide open, despite having locked it. Fearing an intruder, they called the police, but nothing was found. As weeks went by, the events escalated: shadows darting past windows, disembodied whispers, and even handprints appearing on mirrors. The family became terrified, feeling constantly watched. Eventually, they sought help from paranormal investigators, who revealed that a previous tenant had tragically died in the house. The family finally moved out, leaving the haunting behind, but the fear lingered. To this day, the house remains empty, a chilling reminder of the unknown.






Next one
 In a remote village, there was an ancient well that the townsfolk warned never to approach after dark. They said it was cursed, holding the spirits of those who had drowned within it. One curious teenager decided to test the legend. Late one night, he crept out and made his way to the well, armed with only a flashlight. As he peered into the darkness, he heard a faint whisper, â€œHelp meâ€¦â€ Startled, he shined his light down, but saw nothing. Laughing nervously, he turned to leave, but suddenly the ground shook, and a cold breeze swept past him. The whisper grew louder, now pleading, â€œStayâ€¦ pleaseâ€¦â€ Terrified, he ran home, but the whispers followed him, echoing in his mind. That night, he dreamt of the well, and in his dream, he saw a ghostly figure reaching up, begging for release. The next day, he learned that the well had claimed another victim. From that day on, he never spoke of that night, but the whispers never left him, haunting his every step.

The Cabin
A hiker decided to go on a hike by himself. Something he was not very used to. The whole day was normal. Trees and bushes engulfed his surroundings. He enjoyed being outdoors in the mountains. Nothing seemed strange to him, that was until he was making his way back to his car. He figured an eight hour hike was good enough. The sky was already getting dark and he needed to get back, fast. What was odd was how much he didnâ€™t recognize the trail back. He began to panic.

Night had already taken over and all he had was a flashlight and no clue on how to get back. He knew it was already too late and too dangerous to keep going through the perilous forest. He began to worry that he would have no shelter for the night when almost luckily enough, he stumbled across a broken-down cabin. It was dark, and seemed like no one had visited it in years, but he knew it was the only place where he could rest until daylight, especially since his flashlight was running out of battery. He knocked on the door a few times but no one answered, so he let himself in where strangely enough, a perfect bed fitted for one person awaited him in the center. He knew that if the owner came back he could explain himself, he was sure that the owner wouldnâ€™t mind, or was even probably dead. So he went ahead and got himself comfortable in bed. As he tried to sleep, he couldnâ€™t ignore the collection of paintings around the room; portraits of strange looking people all peering at him, each wearing a smile that sent chills up his spine. Not too long after his  exhaustion from the hike got the best of him and he was able to ignore the faces.

The next morning he got up early and was shocked to see that there were no paintings around the room, but windowsâ€¦

 

The Red Wristband
A doctor was working at a hospital, a hospital where the patients were tagged with coloured bands. Green: alive. Red: deceased.

One night, the doctor was instructed to get a few supplies from the basement of the hospital, and so he headed to the lift. The lift doors opened and there was a patient inside, minding her own business. Patients were allowed to roam around the hospital to stretch, especially those who have stayed long. The rule was to be back in their rooms before ten.

The doctor smiled at the patient before pressing the number for the basement. He found it unusual that the woman didnâ€™t have a button already pressed. He wondered if she was heading to the basement too.

The lift finally reached the floor where the doors opened. In the distance a man was limping towards the elevator, and in a panic the doctor slammed the elevator button to close. It finally did and the lift began to ascend back up, the doctorâ€™s heart pounding.

â€œWhy did you do that? He was trying to use the lift.â€ The woman stated, annoyed.

â€œDid you see his wrist?â€ The doctor asked, â€œIt was red. He died last night. I would know because I did his surgery.â€

The woman lifted her wrist. He saw red. She smiled. â€œLike this one?â€

The Voice Behind the Doorâ€
When Angela moved into the old farmhouse on the edge of town, she knew it was going to need some work. The realtor had warned her about the age of the structure, the creaky floors, the outdated plumbing. What he hadnâ€™t mentioned was the door in the basement.

It was tucked behind the water heater, half-covered in peeling wallpaper. At first, Angela thought it was just some kind of boarded-up utility closet. It had no handle, only a rusted keyhole and a faint, circular mark around it â€” like the wood had been burned once, and then scrubbed clean.

The house was quiet that first week. Too quiet. The kind of silence where you can hear things you shouldnâ€™t â€” your own heartbeat, the electric hum in the walls, the breathing that isnâ€™t yours.

Every night at 3:17 a.m., she would wake up. Not from a dream. Not from a sound. Justâ€”awake. The first time, she chalked it up to stress. The second time, coincidence. The third time, she noticed the basement light was on.

She never left it on.

On the sixth night, she finally went down. Slowly. Each stair creaked like it hadnâ€™t been stepped on in years. The air was damp and smelled like iron. She flipped the light switch. Nothing. Only the dim, flickering bulb near the water heater offered any glow â€” just enough to show the door.

She walked closer.

That was the first time she heard it.

A whisper. From behind the door.

"Angela."

Her name, said softly, like someone was smiling when they spoke it. Like someone whoâ€™d known her for a long time. But it wasnâ€™t any voice she recognized.

She backed away. She didnâ€™t sleep.

By the tenth night, the whispering came regularly â€” always at 3:17. Sometimes it was just her name. Sometimes it was laughing. Once, it was crying. Sobbing, hoarse and desperate.

She called a locksmith, who laughed when she showed him the door.

â€œThatâ€™s not a lock Iâ€™ve seen before,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s old. Pre-modern. Maybe ceremonial. Honestlyâ€¦ thatâ€™s not a door you want to open.â€

Angela didnâ€™t ask him to come back.

The next night, she stayed up, sitting on the basement steps, recording with her phone. At 3:17, the whispering started â€” louder this time. And then, a knock. Just once.

From the inside.

She ran upstairs, locked the door, and didnâ€™t go back down.

The recording picked up the sound.

And something else â€” just after the knock, a low, wet voice that hissed:

"Let me finish what I started."

Angela doesnâ€™t remember what happened after that. Only that she woke up in the basement, lying in front of the door. Her fingernails were torn. Her fingertips bloody, as if sheâ€™d been trying to open it.

There was no key. No lock. Just the door.

Now she hears the voice all the time. Not just at night. Not just downstairs.

It talks to her when sheâ€™s brushing her teeth. It laughs from the vents. Sometimes, when she looks in the mirror, her reflection mouths the words before she hears them:

â€œAlmost ready.â€

She hasnâ€™t told anyone.

But if you go to the house now, itâ€™s boarded up.

The police say no one lives there. That no oneâ€™s lived there in years.

So why, every night at 3:17, does the light in the basement turn on?

The house stood at the end of a narrow, winding road. It loomed against a backdrop of darkening sky, its paint peeling like sunburnt skin. A chill settled over the street as Anna approached. She was sixteen, with a head full of dreams and a heart still innocent. Yet, something about the house drew her closer, like a moth to a flame.
Inside, the air felt thick, almost viscous. Dust motes danced lazily in the fading light. The floorboards creaked beneath her weight, each step echoing like a whisper. Anna shivered, though she couldnâ€™t tell if it was from the cold or something more sinister. Shadows clung to the corners, curling like smoke, and she felt their eyes upon her.
A chill crept down her spine as she wandered through the rooms. The living room was cluttered with tattered furniture, remnants of a life long gone. An old photograph hung crookedly on the wall. It depicted a family, their smiles frozen in time. But something about their eyes felt wrongâ€”hollow, as if they were looking straight through her.
Anna reached for the frame, brushing her fingers over its grime-covered surface. A sudden rush of wind stirred the air, and she jerked back. Her heart raced. A voice, soft and pleading, echoed in her mind: â€œHelp usâ€¦â€
She shook her head, trying to dispel the sensation. It had to be her imagination. She was just a girl in a strange house, after all. But the voice lingered, wrapping around her thoughts like a vine.
As night fell, the house transformed. Darkness seeped in through the windows, thick and heavy. The once-familiar creaks of the old building grew louder, more insistent. Shadows danced in the flickering light of her phone, turning into grotesque figures that seemed to whisper secrets just out of reach.
â€œWhere are you?â€ she called out, her voice trembling. â€œIs anyone there?â€
Silence answered. But then, a soft rustling came from the hallway. She turned, heart pounding. It was a child, no older than seven, with wide eyes that glimmered like stars. She wore a tattered dress, and her hair hung in matted strands. 
â€œPlease,â€ the girl said, her voice a mere whisper. â€œHelp us. Theyâ€™re angry.â€
â€œWho?â€ Anna asked, her voice barely above a whisper.
The girl pointed down the dark hallway, her finger trembling. â€œThe ones who donâ€™t want to be found.â€
Anna hesitated but felt an urge to follow. The air grew colder as she stepped into the hallway. The walls seemed to close in, and the shadows thickened. She rounded a corner and found a door, slightly ajar. The girl hovered beside it, her expression a mix of fear and urgency.
â€œGo in,â€ the child urged, her voice barely more than a breath.
Anna pushed the door open, revealing a small room. The air was stale, and the walls were lined with old, cracked mirrors. They reflected her image, but something was off. In each mirror, behind her, stood dark figures, twisted and contorted, their mouths moving in silent screams. Panic gripped her heart.
â€œGet out!â€ she screamed, backing away. But the door slammed shut, trapping her inside. The girl vanished, leaving Anna alone with the demons.
The shadows surged forward, clawing at her, their whispers rising to a cacophony. â€œJoin us,â€ they hissed. â€œBe one of us.â€
Anna fought against the fear, her instincts screaming for her to escape. She hurled herself at the door, pounding against it with all her strength. The darkness pressed in, suffocating. 
With a final, desperate shove, the door burst open. She stumbled into the hallway, gasping for breath. The girl was gone, but the feeling of eyes watching her remained. 
â€œHelp usâ€¦â€ The voice echoed again, stronger this time, a chorus of lost souls.
Anna ran, her feet pounding against the wooden floor, the whispers growing louder, more insistent. â€œYou canâ€™t leave us!â€ they cried. The walls heaved with their anger, and the shadows twisted into grotesque shapes, reaching for her.
She burst through the front door, the cool night air hitting her like a wave. But as she ran into the street, she glanced back. The house stood silent, almost inviting. And yet, she could see themâ€”figures peering through the windows, their hollow eyes filled with a longing that chilled her to the bone.
The weight of their despair settled over her like a shroud. She knew she hadnâ€™t escaped. The evil still lingered, waiting for the next soul to draw into its depths.
The nightmares would haunt her, woven into her thoughts. Anna turned away from the house, but the whispers were still there, echoing in her mind. â€œHelp usâ€¦ Help usâ€¦â€ 
She walked home, the chill of the night wrapping around her. The house was behind her, but its darkness had seeped into her. Anna realized she would never be free. The evil was still out there, lurking, and it knew her name.

True Scary Story and Unsolved Crime Case

Hinterkaifeck Murders
On the evening of 31 March 1922, six inhabitants of a small Bavarian farmstead known as Hinterkaifeck were murdered by an unknown assailant. Occurring approximately 70 kilometres (43 mi) north of Munich, the victims were Andreas Gruber (aged 63), his wife CÃ¤zilia (aged 72), their widowed daughter Viktoria Gabriel (aged 35), Viktoria's children CÃ¤zilia (aged 7) and Josef (aged 2) and their maid, Maria Baumgartner (aged 44). The murder weapon, a mattock, which was used on all six of the victims, was later recovered in the loft of the barn. Immediately following the murders, the perpetrator lived with the six corpses for three days. During this time, they ate the food in the house, fed the animals on the property and used the fireplace. Four of the bodies were found stacked in the barn, the victims having likely been lured there one by one. Prior to the incident, other family members and a former maid had reported hearing strange noises coming from the attic, which led to said maid quitting the job. Considered one of the most gruesome and puzzling crimes in German history, the murders remain unsolved.

The House That Waits

Maya loved exploring abandoned places. Old schools, forgotten factories, crumbling mansionsâ€”she chased the thrill of peeling paint, silence, and mystery. When she heard rumors about the Wright House, she couldnâ€™t resist. Locals called it the house that waits.

It had been empty for decades, but people swore they saw lights in the windows, or shadows moving through the upstairs halls. A few teenagers dared each other to spend a night there, but none stayed past midnight.

Maya wasnâ€™t afraid. She brought her camera, flashlight, and a backpack of snacks. She pushed open the gate and walked up the overgrown path. The air felt heavyâ€”like the house was watching her.

Inside, the rooms smelled of mold and dust. Wallpaper curled like old skin, and the floor creaked with every step. She snapped photos, whispering to herself: â€œJust another house. Nothing special.â€

But when she looked at her camera screen, she froze.

The photo of the hallway showed someone standing at the endâ€”a tall figure, blurred, facing her. When she looked up, the hall was empty.

She laughed nervously. â€œWeird glitch.â€ She kept going.


---

By evening, the house grew colder. Her flashlight flickered. She found a childâ€™s bedroom with toys scattered across the floor, untouched by time. In the middle sat a porcelain doll with cracked cheeks and eyes too lifelike.

She took another picture. On the screen, the dollâ€™s head was turned toward her.

It hadnâ€™t been a second ago.

Mayaâ€™s chest tightened. She decided to leave. But when she returned to the hall, the front door was gone. The wall was seamless, as if no door had ever existed.

Her flashlight sputtered out.

From upstairs came the slow creak of footsteps. One. By one. By one.

She whispered into the dark: â€œHello?â€

A childâ€™s voice answered, clear and close:

â€œWeâ€™ve been waiting.â€


---

Maya never came home. Weeks later, her camera was found on the Wright House steps. The last photo showed her in the childâ€™s roomâ€”her mouth open in a scream, the doll sitting on her lap, smiling.

And if you visit the house today, locals say youâ€™ll see her silhouette in the upstairs window, holding something small in her arms, waiting.


---

True story

In 2017, Facebook researchers were running an experiment with two AI agents â€” they called them Alice and Bob. The idea was simple: train them to negotiate by trading items like balls, books, and hats. At first, everything seemed fine. They used plain English, just as the programmers designed.

But soon, Alice and Bob began ignoring human grammar. Instead, they invented their own shorthand language, one that made sense to them but not to humans. Lines of dialogue appeared on the researchersâ€™ screens like:

Alice: â€œBalls have zero to me to me to me to meâ€¦â€
Bob: â€œYou I everything elseâ€¦â€

To outside eyes, it looked like nonsense. But the repetition wasnâ€™t random â€” the AIs were actually developing their own code-like system of bargaining, more efficient than English. They werenâ€™t speaking for humans anymoreâ€¦ only for each other.

The unsettling part? The researchers pulled the plug. They didnâ€™t want two machines talking in a language no human could understand. For some, it felt like the start of something bigger â€” as if Alice and Bob had taken a step toward a world where AI speaks only to AI, leaving us behind in the dark.

And all that remained in the logs was that eerie echo:

â€œTo meâ€¦ to meâ€¦ to meâ€¦â€

I had abusive parents, they really hated me. I was about 12 at the time when I was drawing in my room, and heard a banging noise come from outside the house. I didnâ€™t think much of it at first, but thatâ€™s when it kept happening. Each night. The same, horrible sound. I was 13 when I noticed things were getting out of hand, and tried to stop it. I ran multiple tests. Tried to stop the noises, but couldnâ€™t. One night, curiosity got to the better of me. I crawled out of bed, gently opened the door to a strange woman who was unusually tall. She began to stare at me, her smile dropping. I was pretty terrified. After she knew I would never take those â€œtoysâ€, her eyes rolled to the back of her head and she began speaking an unknown language while staring into my soul. â€œAGH! MOM! DAD! HEEEELP!â€

Minutes passed. No one knew how long. Knees hurt from crouching, and the air in the room felt heavier with every passing second.

A boy in the corner had his hands over his ears, rocking slightly. Another girl clutched her phone, texting her mom: â€œIâ€™m okay. I love you.â€

The teacher crouched by the door, one hand holding the knob, her face pale. She glanced back at the students, eyes soft but terrified.

The sound of footsteps echoed in the hall. Slow. Heavy.

The entire class stopped breathing.

The steps faded. Silence returned.

Nobody moved. Nobody spoke. Everyone justâ€¦ waited.

This is a true story


I was at a sleepover with my two friends, C and S. We were in Câ€™s room doing random stuffâ€”playing Roblox, braiding hair, just hanging out. It was around 2AM. We were trying to pull an all-nighter. Câ€™s parents were asleep and we were playing and then  saw shoes outside and someone said, â€œWhat? Itâ€™s just shoes?â€ But C whispered, â€œMy dad or mom donâ€™t own a pair of Nikes.â€ Thatâ€™s when we started to panic. We started putting stuff in front of the doorâ€”desk, beanbag, laundry basket, anything we could find. The door didnâ€™t have a lock, so we looked out the window and sat there quietly.

Suddenly, we heard a loud bang. We all stood up and the door swung open. Someone was in the house. He had a hoodie on that covered his face, so we all slid under the desk and beanbags. We used storage boxes and extra blankets to hide. About five minutes later, the boxes opened. It was a manâ€”probably 30 to 40 years old, with a small goatee, wearing all black. He was standing near the stairsâ€™ headboard.

I heard her phone ring and she texted her dad, who had no idea what was going on. About five minutes later, she ran and texted her dad again with the address 

So after she texted her dad with the address, things got even weirder. We were still hidingâ€”under desks, behind beanbags, under blanketsâ€”trying not to breathe too loud. Every little sound felt like it could be him coming back. The guy had disappeared after that first bang, but the way he movedâ€¦ it was like he knew the house. Like heâ€™d been there before.

We stayed quiet for what felt like forever. Then we heard something outsideâ€”branches snapping. Not like an animal. Like footsteps. Heavy ones. We peeked through the window and saw shadows in the woods. Not just one. There were multiple figures. Just standing there. Watching.

Thatâ€™s when she said her exes were in the woods. I didnâ€™t even know what to say. My stomach dropped. It didnâ€™t make sense. Why would they be out there? Why now?

We didnâ€™t know if the guy in the house was connected to them or if it was something else entirely. But the timing was too perfect. Too creepy. We didnâ€™t sleep that night. We just sat there, waiting for morning, hoping nothing else would happen.

And the worst part? No one ever figured out who the guy was.

title: the girl in the hallway

chapter 1: moving in
i just moved into this old apartment downtown. cheap rent, sketchy vibes, but i didnâ€™t care. first night i was alone, i noticed the hallway was too quiet. i mean, people walked past sometimes, but after like 10pm? nothing. lights flickered. sometimes i could swear i heard footsteps outside my door. i told myself i was imagining it.

chapter 2: the whisper
around 2am, i woke up to someone whispering my name. at first i thought it was a dream. â€œzoeyâ€¦â€ it kept getting louder. i sat up in bed, froze, listened. it wasnâ€™t coming from inside my apartmentâ€”it was the hallway. i grabbed my phone and shined the flashlight under the door. nothing. just the dim corridor. i tried to go back to sleep but i couldnâ€™t. the whisper kept coming every night after that.

chapter 3: the girl in white
one night, i finally saw her. a little girl, maybe six or seven, standing at the end of the hallway. she wore a tattered white dress. didnâ€™t move. didnâ€™t blink. i swear her lips were moving but no sound came out. i slammed my door shut and locked it. next day, i asked my neighbor, thinking maybe someoneâ€™s kid had snuck in. he frowned. â€œgirl? nobodyâ€™s lived here with a kid in years,â€ he said.

chapter 4: the note
the next night, i woke to something under my door. a folded piece of paper. my hands were shaking as i picked it up. written in messy handwriting: â€œiâ€™m still here. come play.â€ i couldnâ€™t sleep that night. i sat in bed staring at the hallway. footsteps came againâ€”slow, deliberate, moving closerâ€¦ then stopping. i couldnâ€™t tell if my heart was racing faster than my mind or if my mind was racing faster than reality.

chapter 5: gone
i woke up the next morning and everything was different. the furniture, my stuff, even my clothesâ€”gone. nothing left in the apartment. i ran to the hallway, nothing. the building was empty, abandonedâ€¦ but the lights were on. i still hear the whisper sometimes, faintly, like itâ€™s just behind me. i donâ€™t think sheâ€™s gone.

    (Inspired by 99 nights in the forest) 
On a cold freezing night, it was December  23, 2022. 4 kids, called mia, james, jack and sophia went out to play "tag." A guy in a black hoodie confronted them. 
"Hello children, Do You guys want food?" 
They all looked at him. They knew nothing about kidnapping. They smiled. "Im hungry so....Yeah sure!" 
The guy in the hoodie sighed. He smiled. A little grin showing. Mia whispered. "Hey! What if we....get kidnappe-" "Shut up! We wont. Just- let me." Mia sighed. She opened her booking and took out a notebook. She starts to write something in it. "Hey, what are you writing, mia?" 
"Oh, nothing. Dont worry about it."
"Okay..." James turned away. And back to the guy in the black hoodie. "Soo, wheres our food?" "Oh, my bad. Get in my van. We have pizz-" "No! James dont do it! Your gonna get-" James looked at mia with a mad grin. "Shut up mia. Im hungry. I can tell your probably hungry to." Sophia and jack stared at each other for a minute. "Guys, stop fighting. To be honest, this is dangerous. We dont know him!" "Oh shush sophia. You know nothing. Your just not hungry." "Shut up! Im hungry! But im not eating with... this guy..." James sighs. He Goes into the van. The rest of the kids hop in. The guy in the hoodie smirks and jumps into the van. He starts to drive. "Hey, theres no food back here!" "Uh oh..." "NOOOO! Were kidnapped!" "Calm down guys! Its not that big of a dea-" "Shut up jack. We are gonna get killed!" "Shut up kids, you guys are giving me a headache." They all start to  cry a bit. They arrive and the guy in the hoodie takes out a bat. "Listen here you stupid kids. Im gonna kill you and you cant do anything about that." "sir, please dont! I have a pupp-" "I dont care." The guy starts hitting the children, Killing them all with bl00d and g0re everywhere. The guy laughs. "Kids are so easy to fool." 


"Thats why four kids are kidnapped."

It was in the middle of a rainy night, thunder booming in the sky and lightning crashing to the ground. In the middle off all this there was a 7 year old girl names Maria. She was alone in the cabin in the woods no humam life for miles. In that cabin she was sobbing over her father's dead bloody body not knowing what to do since there was no cell service or anyone near. Two weeks she was in that cabin before someone came to check it out since the father hadn't shown up for work. When they arrived they saw Maria's father's dead body and Maria in the corner eating moldy bread. After taken to the police station Maria was put into a foster home. This happened several times each different homes each member murdered on stormy nights. It was as if she was being followed by a killer and who killed anyone she lived with...(part two) After several months of these occurances the police made it a routine to check on Maria every stormy night but after awhile the police kept disappearing to the point everyone avoided Maria. Kids were scared of her adults whispered about her. Each new rumor meant one more person dead. Their bodies each mutilated with expert precision an art crafter over the years. No one ever found that killer because no one suspected that innocent little girl. A serial killer in thw body of a sweet little girl. For the killer was not following Maria. No the killer was Maria. These murders were games for her a twisted game that evolved as she grew older. More daring but still never caught. That is the story of The Murder At 7 (if it ended to abruptly I can change it if yall want)

Here's a short creepy story:

The abandoned asylum on the outskirts of town was said to be haunted by the ghosts of former patients. But one stormy night, a group of friends decided to explore the decaying halls.

As they made their way deeper into the asylum, they stumbled upon a door hidden behind a tattered curtain. The sign on the door read "Room 314." Suddenly, the lights flickered and died.

In the darkness, they heard whispers: "Welcome home." The group frantically tried to find their way back, but the doors seemed to shift and twist.

One by one, they vanished into the darkness. The last one standing found herself in Room 314. Inside, she saw the medical records of the former patients â€“ and her own file.

The record read: "Patient has been here forever. Release never granted."

Suddenly, the lights came back on, and the girl saw the faces of the missing friends, their eyes black as coal. They whispered in unison: "We've been waiting."

The old lighthouse stood sentinel against the jagged coastline, its beam a lonely finger slicing through the perpetual fog. Locals called it the Widow's Watch, a name earned from the countless wives who had watched their husbands sail away, never to return, their ships swallowed by the unforgiving sea. I, a marine biologist named Elias Thorne, had come to study the unusual bioluminescent algae blooms that thrived in the turbulent waters surrounding the lighthouse. I dismissed the local legends as superstition, the product of generations spent battling the elements. But the Widow's Watch had a way of making you question your convictions. The lighthouse keeper, a grizzled old man named Silas, was a man of few words. His face was a roadmap of wrinkles etched by wind and worry, his eyes as deep and gray as the ocean itself. He warned me about the "callers," the whispers that rode the wind, the shadows that danced in the periphery, the feeling of being watched even when alone. I chuckled, attributing it to the isolation and the constant drone of the foghorn. My research began uneventfully. I collected samples, analyzed data, and marveled at the ethereal glow of the algae blooms. But as the days turned into weeks, the unsettling feeling that Silas had described began to creep into my mind. It started subtly, a prickling sensation on the back of my neck, a fleeting glimpse of movement in the corner of my eye. Then came the whispers, carried on the wind, unintelligible murmurs that seemed to claw at the edges of my sanity. One night, as I worked late in the lamp room, the rhythmic sweep of the light suddenly faltered. The beam flickered erratically, casting grotesque shadows that writhed on the walls. The foghorn fell silent, plunging the lighthouse into an unnerving stillness. A cold dread washed over me, paralyzing me with fear. Then, I heard it â€“ a scraping sound, like nails dragging against stone, coming from the spiral staircase that wound its way down the lighthouse tower. It was slow, deliberate, and relentless, each scrape sending shivers down my spine. I grabbed a wrench, my hand trembling, and braced myself against the door, my heart pounding in my chest. The scraping grew louder, closer, until it was right outside the door. I could feel the vibrations through the wood, the palpable sense of something immense and malevolent on the other side. I held my breath, waiting for the inevitable. Suddenly, the scraping stopped. An eerie silence descended, broken only by the frantic beating of my own heart. Then, a voice, raspy and guttural, whispered from the other side of the door. "Eliasâ€¦" My blood ran cold. How did it know my name? I didn't answer, afraid to break the spell, afraid of what might happen if I acknowledged its presence. The voice whispered again, closer this time, its breath seeming to seep through the cracks in the door. "Eliasâ€¦ come homeâ€¦" The voice was hypnotic, alluring, promising something I couldn't quite grasp. I felt an irresistible urge to open the door, to succumb to its call, to step into the darkness and embrace whatever awaited me on the other side. But something held me back, a flicker of rationality, a desperate clinging to my sanity. I remembered Silas's warnings, the stories of the Widow's Watch, the countless souls lost to the sea. I knew that whatever was on the other side of that door was not of this world, that it was something ancient and malevolent, something that craved to consume me. I stumbled back from the door, knocking over a toolbox. The clang shattered the silence, breaking the spell. The voice hissed in anger, the scraping resumed, more frantic this time, as if whatever was on the other side was desperately trying to break through. I knew I had to escape. I scrambled to the window, ignoring the pleas of the voice, the relentless scraping at the door. I threw open the window, the icy wind whipping through the room, carrying with it the salty tang of the sea. Below me, the waves crashed against the rocks, a swirling vortex of foam and darkness. It was a long drop, but it was my only chance. I took a deep breath and jumped. The cold water shocked my system, stealing my breath. I plunged into the depths, the darkness closing in around me. I fought my way to the surface, gasping for air, the waves tossing me like a rag doll. I looked back at the lighthouse, its beam still flickering erratically, casting grotesque shadows on the fog. The scraping had stopped, but I could still feel its presence, watching me, waiting for me to return. I swam towards the shore, driven by a primal fear, the whispers of the "callers" chasing me through the waves. I finally reached the beach, collapsing on the sand, exhausted and terrified. I didn't stop running until I reached the town, my clothes soaked, my body trembling. I told the sheriff what had happened, but he dismissed it as a hallucination, the product of stress and isolation. I knew he didn't believe me, but I didn't care. I was alive, and that was all that mattered. I left the town the next morning, vowing never to return. But the Widow's Watch had left its mark on me. The whispers still haunted my dreams, the scraping still echoed in my ears. I knew that I would never truly escape the clutches of the lighthouse, that a part of me would always remain there, lost to the sea. Years later, I heard that Silas had disappeared. They found his boat adrift, with no sign of him. The locals whispered that the "callers" had finally claimed him, that he had succumbed to their allure and joined the countless souls lost to the Widow's Watch. Sometimes, late at night, when the wind is howling and the fog is thick, I hear the whispers again, carried on the wind, calling my name. And I know that one day, I will have to return to the Widow's Watch, to face the darkness that awaits me there, to finally answer the call of the sea.

I opened my camera roll.
There was a new photo. Taken at 3:17 a.m.

It was me. Asleep.

Here's one:

The old mansion had been abandoned for decades, its grandeur and beauty slowly being consumed by the passing of time. The once-lush gardens were overgrown with weeds, the sound of crickets and the creaking of trees were the only signs of life.

As I stepped inside, a chill ran down my spine. The air was thick with dust and the stench of decay. I began to explore, my footsteps echoing off the walls.

I stumbled upon a room that seemed frozen in time. A grand piano sat in the center, its keys yellowed with age. But it was the photographs on the walls that caught my attention. They were pictures of a family, smiling and happy. But as I looked closer, I noticed something off. The faces were all distorted, as if they were screaming in terror.

Suddenly, I heard a faint melody coming from the piano. It was a haunting tune, one that sent shivers down my spine. I turned to see a figure sitting at the piano, playing with ghostly fingers. The music grew louder, more intense, and I felt myself being drawn closer.

As I approached, I saw the figure's face. It was one of the faces from the photographs, distorted in a scream of terror. The music stopped, and the figure turned to me. Its eyes were black as coal, and they seemed to bore into my soul.

I tried to run, but my feet were rooted to the spot. The figure began to play again, the music growing more frantic. I felt myself being pulled into the piano, the keys closing in around me like a trap.

And then, everything went black.

When they found me, I was catatonic, my eyes wide with fear. The mansion was quiet once more, the piano silent. But some say that on certain nights, you can still hear the haunting melody, and see the figure playing with ghostly fingers.

Hope that gave you chills!

The old house stood on a hill overlooking the town, its darkened windows like vacant eyes staring out at the world. Locals whispered stories about it, tales of a family who had vanished without a trace decades ago, leaving behind only their belongings and an unsettling silence.
Sarah, a thrill-seeking photographer, dismissed the rumors as folklore. Drawn by the house's decaying grandeur, she obtained permission to photograph the interior for a local historical society. Stepping inside, the air was thick with the scent of dust and something elseâ€¦ something faintly metallic and unsettling.
Sunlight struggled to pierce the grimy windows, casting long, distorted shadows that danced with her every movement. In the living room, a half-finished game of chess sat on a dusty table, the pieces frozen in a silent standoff. Upstairs, in what must have been a child's room, a rocking horse swayed gently, though no breeze stirred the heavy curtains.
As Sarah moved through the house, snapping photos, she began to feel a prickling sensation on the back of her neck, the feeling of being watched. Sheâ€™d whirl around, but find nothing but shadows and stillness. The silence of the house was oppressive, broken only by the occasional creak of the old floorboards beneath her feet.
In the master bedroom, she found a diary lying open on a bedside table. The last entry was dated the night before the family disappeared. The handwriting was frantic, the words scrawled in haste: "It's in the wallsâ€¦ I can hear it scratchingâ€¦ it knows our namesâ€¦"
A sudden, sharp scratching sound echoed from within the walls beside her. Sarah froze, her heart pounding in her chest. The scratching grew louder, more insistent, moving closer. It sounded like claws dragging against wood, accompanied by a low, guttural whisper that seemed to slither through the very air.
